(Number of posts/thousands of United States dollars)

The overall decrease of $1.1 million for the 10 special political missions is attributable primarily to: (a) the planned drawdown of UNTMIS and adjustment made to mission activities and services to cover only 10-month period up to 31 October 2026, in accordance with second phase of the mission transition as outlined in Security Council Resolution 2753 (2024), and proposed abolishment of 11 posts as at 1 January 2026; (b) reduced requirements for National Professional Officers in UNMHA due to the application of higher vacancy rates and the abolishment of two National Professional Officers posts and establishment of two Local level posts instead; (c) the application of higher vacancy rates for United Nations police officers in BINUH; (d) reduced requirements for consultants owing to the higher reliance on in-house expertise in UNOWAS and the UN Verification Mission in Colombia, as well as lower estimates for travel for civilian observers in the United Nations support to CNMC; (d) lower requirements for ground transportation due to reduced rental costs in the UN Verification Mission in Colombia with the implementation of the UN Fleet lease contract for the soft-skin fleet; and (e) reduced requirements for communications and information technology equipment and its maintenance, through de-prioritization of non-essential activities in some missions. The decrease was offset in part by additional requirements: (a) for military observers owing to an increase in the mission subsistence allowance rates and the application of lower vacancy rates in UNMHA and the UN Verification Mission in Colombia; (b) for air operations in the UN Verification Mission in Colombia to support mandate implementation in the locations outside Bogota and ensure connectivity between location; and (c) for the construction of a new road and parking area, fuel station, infrastructure networks and other security enhancements in the UNSMIL complex.

The proposed vacancy rates applied in the budget take into account the experience to date. The assumptions considered for the proposed vacancy factors include the 12-month average vacancy rate in 2024 and the actual vacancy rate as at 31 March 2025. The lower of the two was used as the budgeted vacancy rate. This is in line with the policy guidance to improve the accuracy and consistency of the vacancy factors applied in the proposed budgets for 2026 and to ensure that proposed vacancy rates are based, as much as possible, on actual rates. A vacancy rate of 50 per cent has been applied in the calculation of costs for the proposed establishment of new posts and positions, or posts and positions proposed for reassignment.
For the sake of brevity, the present document will include a section on extrabudgetary resources only for those missions that have projected extrabudgetary resources in 2025 or 2026.
II.	Cross-cutting information
Gender perspective

Special political missions are guided by Security Council resolutions on women and peace and security agenda and mandate the incorporation of a gender perspective into the political work of the United Nations, including in special political missions. The missions are also guided by General Assembly resolution 75/100 on the comprehensive review of special political missions, in which the Assembly reaffirmed the important role of women in the prevention and resolution of conflicts and in peacebuilding and recognised the importance of the equal and effective participation and the full involvement of women at all levels, at all stages and in all aspects of the peaceful settlement of disputes, conflict prevention and conflict resolution.

Specific examples of how special political missions integrate a gender perspective into their operational activities, deliverables and results are given under the individual missions in the present report.
Disability inclusion

In line with the United Nations Disability Inclusion Strategy, special political missions review the Strategy with a view to further advancing disability inclusion through inclusive messaging, awareness-raising and promoting the Strategy through their work, including in political and peace processes. The missions also support mitigating measures to overcome accessibility challenges, in addition to the efforts undertaken by relevant United Nations entities to ensure the accessibility of facilities, platforms, security and other infrastructure to facilitate easy access and use by persons with disabilities.
Evaluation activities

The Department of Political and Peacebuilding Affairs will support the biennial assessment by the Office of Internal Oversight Services on strengthening the role of evaluation and the application of evaluation findings on programme design, delivery and policy directives. Mission-specific evaluation activities are described, as applicable, under the specific missions in the present report.
III.	Special political missions

text: 1.	United Nations Office for West Africa and the Sahel

children.text: A.	Proposed programme plan for 2026 and programme performance in 2024
Overall orientation
Mandates and background

The United Nations Office for West Africa and the Sahel (UNOWAS) is responsible for conflict prevention and ensuring sustainable peace and security in West Africa and the Sahel. Its mandate derives from the exchanges of letters between the Secretary-General and the President of the Security Council (S/2016/88 and S/2016/89, S/2016/1128 and S/2016/1129, S/2019/1009 and S/2020/85 and S/2023/70 and S/2023/71), as well as Council resolution 2349 (2017). The mission’s current mandate will expire on 31 January 2026.

UNOWAS is mandated  to monitor political developments in West Africa and the Sahel, and carry out  good offices to support conflict prevention, peacebuilding, sustaining peace and mediation efforts in the subregion, mindful of the sustainable development context; enhance regional and subregional partnerships to address cross-border and cross-cutting threats to peace and security; support, through political advocacy and playing a convening role, the implementation of the United Nations integrated strategy for the Sahel; and promote good governance, respect for the rule of law, human rights and gender mainstreaming in conflict prevention, management and resolution.
Programme of work
Objective
The objective, to which this mission contributes, is to achieve peace and security in West Africa and the Sahel.
Strategy and external factors for 2026
To contribute to the objective, the mission will:

Strengthen its early warning and conflict prevention and resolution actions with relevant partners, with a focus on West African countries undergoing political transitions and those scheduled to hold elections in 2026; de-escalate crises relating to governance-related challenges; lead regional and international diplomatic engagements to build consensus on regional responses; support regional solutions to cross-cutting threats to peace and security; and monitor and assess political developments in the region;

Enhance partnerships with regional institutions, civil society organizations, and United Nations entities to address regional peace and security challenges, focusing on root causes of instability and insecurity in the region, while reinforcing the peace-security-development nexus; and conduct high-level advocacy to facilitate humanitarian assistance and access to critical social services by populations affected by conflict and insecurity;

Accelerate the implementation of women and peace, security and youth, peace and security agendas through the promotion of involvement of women and young people in political and decision-making processes and mediation initiatives; and advance the promotion of good governance and respect for human rights and the rule of law; and
Intensify its analytical work, including on governance and the adverse implications of climate change.
The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
Prevention and mitigation of conflicts through consensual political processes, including in countries undergoing political transitions;

Strengthened regional and subregional cross-border responses and coherent, comprehensive and integrated approaches to challenges relating to climate change, transnational organized crime, illicit trafficking, farmer and herder dynamics, intercommunal violence, terrorism, violent extremism and humanitarian access;
Mainstreaming of gender and youth participation in conflict prevention, management and resolution activities; and
Strengthened initiatives to address violations of human rights and international humanitarian law and improve security sector governance.

With regard to cooperation with other entities, UNOWAS works with the African Union, ECOWAS, the Mano River Union, the Lake Chad Basin Commission, the Accra Initiative, the Liptako-Gourma Authority, the Gulf of Guinea Commission, the African Development Bank, national human rights institutions and other civil society groups in the region to strengthen and harmonize regional capacities for conflict prevention and resolution, peacebuilding and sustaining peace; advance good governance and respect for human rights and the rule of law and the participation of women and young people in political and decision-making processes; and support regional responses to address climate change and cross-border threats to peace and security.

With regard to inter-agency coordination and liaison, UNOWAS collaborates with the Development Coordination Office and resident coordinators, humanitarian coordinators, UN country teams, UN agencies, funds and programmes based in Dakar and across the region and other UN partners to create political space for humanitarian access and developmental initiatives. Working with the Special Coordinator for Development in the Sahel, UNOWAS promotes the UN integrated strategy for the Sahel and supports cost-effective, innovative approaches.  It coordinates with the United Nations Regional Office for Central Africa (UNOCA) on transregional issues affecting West and Central Africa, including terrorism in the Lake Chad Basin, farmer-herder conflicts, climate security, piracy and maritime security in the Gulf of Guinea.
In relation to the external factors, the overall plan for 2026 is based on the following planning assumptions:
Demand for UNOWAS good offices to facilitate political dialogue and defuse political tensions, and to support countries undergoing political transitions and institutional reforms;

Heads of State and Governments of West Africa, ECOWAS, the Lake Chad Basin Commission, the Mano River Union, the African Union, the Gulf of Guinea Commission and the Accra Initiative demonstrate political will for sustained support to regional peace and security mechanisms and commitment to mobilizing resources required to address challenges to peace and stability;
The ECOWAS early warning and response mechanisms and other regional conflict prevention instruments are operational at the national and regional levels;
The international community remains committed to supporting the countries of the region and regional and subregional organizations in addressing governance and security challenges;
Peacebuilding and peace consolidation efforts by regional and subregional organizations and other partners continue;

Political and technical level engagements with UNOCA in support of the Gulf of Guinea Commission and the Interregional Coordination Centre for Maritime Safety and Security in the Gulf of Guinea continue;
Political commitment on the part of national, regional, and international partners to work with the United Nations in the context of the United Nations Integrated Strategy for the Sahel;
Governments in the region remain willing to engage with UNOWAS and other partners to improve human rights and rule of law.
Programme performance in 2024
Conducive environment for peaceful and inclusive electoral processes in West Africa and the Sahel

In 2024, UNOWAS led initiatives to prevent conflict and defuse electoral tensions in Ghana, Mauritania, and Senegal, in collaboration with national and regional partners. For Ghana’s December 2024 elections, the Mission promoted an inclusive, transparent process through stakeholder engagement, and supporting the “I Pledge for Peace” campaign led by the National Peace Council. In Senegal’s March 2024 elections, the Mission engaged with political and electoral stakeholders to ensure peaceful elections. For Mauritania’s June 2024 presidential election, the Mission engaged with political and electoral stakeholders, advocating for dialogue to address challenges, strengthen social cohesion, and promote national dialogue and electoral reforms.
Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see Table 3).
Table 3 – Performance measure

children.text: Planned results for 2026
Result 1: Enhanced political dialogue throughout West Africa and the Sahel – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026:

In 2024, the Mission led 38 high-level engagements to enhance dialogue and facilitate rapprochement between ECOWAS and transitioning countries, Burkina Faso, Guinea, Mali, and Niger. These efforts improved bilateral relations and donor engagement, as well as reduced tensions. In response to the announced withdrawal of Burkina Faso, Mali and Niger from ECOWAS, the Mission promoted dialogue to rebuild trust, preserve regional integration, and strengthen cooperation on peace and security. This created a conducive environment for dialogue, eased tensions, and prevented further deterioration of the security situation.

In 2026, the Mission will continue fostering political consensus, stability, and social cohesion, supporting inclusive governance, rule of law, and human rights throughout West Africa and the Sahel. The Mission will advocate for regional security cooperation to address threats to peace and human security, prioritizing nationally led peacebuilding and prevention initiatives, aligned with the Pact for the Future.
Progress towards the 2026 objective and target is presented in the performance measure below (see Table 4).
Table 4 – Performance measure

children.text: Result 2: Enhanced regional and sub-regional partnerships to respond to cross-border and cross-cutting security challenges – Proposed programme in 2024 and target for 2026

In 2024, the Mission worked with regional and subregional partners to strengthen peace and security in West Africa and the Sahel and to safeguard regional integration. The Mission signed Memorandums of Understanding with ECOWAS and the Mano River Union (MRU), which enhanced existing regional partnerships and supported the evaluation of the Yaoundé Architecture for maritime safety and security in the Gulf of Guinea. In response to the weakening of regional security cooperation mechanisms, the Mission advocated for continued support for the Accra Initiative, the preservation of the Multinational Joint Task Force in the Lake Chad Basin and the full implementation of Security Council resolution 2719 (2023). Additionally, the Mission fostered cooperation and peaceful dialogue between Coastal states and Sahelian countries to contain the spread of terrorism and violent extremism.
Lessons learned and planned change

The key lesson learned is the importance of regional ownership in ensuring effective lasting security arrangements A major challenge was the trust deficit between some member states hindering cooperation on security matters. UNOWAS promoted kinetic and non-kinetic security approaches, with successful models from the Multinational Joint Task Force (MNJTF) and the Lake Chad Regional Stabilization Strategy offering valuable insights. Going forward, the Mission will work to bridge trust gaps, promote ownership of security initiatives and encourage integrated multi-dimensional responses to regional security challenges.
Expected progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 5)

children.text: B.	Proposed post and non-post resource requirements for 2026
The following abbreviations are used in the tables: ASG, Assistant Secretary-General; FS, Field Service; GS, General Service; NPO, National Professional Officer; USG; Under-Secretary-General.
Resource requirements (regular budget) – Table 7 – Financial resources
(Thousands of United States dollars)
Table 8 – Human resources
a	Includes one general temporary assistance position.

The proposed resource requirements for 2026 for UNOWAS amount to $15,960,200 (net of staff assessment) and would provide for the deployment of one military adviser and one police adviser ($107,000), salaries and common staff costs ($11,153,900) for 49 international posts (1 Under-Secretary-General, 1 Assistant Secretary-General, 2 D-1, 9 P-5, 16 P-4, 13 P-3, 1 P-2 and 6 Field Service), 30 national posts (9 National Professional Officer and 22 Local level), and 1 Local level position (general temporary assistance), and operational costs ($4,699,300), comprising costs for official travel ($788,000), facilities and infrastructure ($209,300), ground transportation ($97,400), air operations ($2,153,200), communications and information technology ($620,000) and other supplies, services and equipment ($831,400).
In 2026, no change is proposed to the number and levels of the posts.

The mission’s approved 2025 staffing table includes one general temporary assistance position. It is proposed that this position, Finance and Budget Assistant (Local level), be continued in 2026, to support and maintain internal control over the financial transactions of the mission.

Vacancy rates of 15.6 per cent for international posts and 0.8 per cent for Local level posts and position, based on the actual average vacancy rates in 2024, and zero per cent for National Professional Officer posts, based on the actual vacancy rate in March 2025, have been applied to the estimates. A vacancy rate of zero per cent has been applied to the estimates for military and police advisers on the basis of the actual vacancy rate in March 2025.

The increase in requirements for 2026 compared with the appropriation for 2025 is attributable mainly to increased requirements for civilian personnel, owing to: (a) the application of the latest salary rates for international staff; and (b) the application of lower vacancy rate of zero per cent compared with the rate of 8.3 per cent applied in 2025 for National Professional Officers. The increase is offset in part by: (a) the non-provisioning of resources for consultants and consulting services in 2026 with the use of in-house capacity; (b) reduced requirements for air operations in line with historical flight hour utilization rates; (c) reduced requirements for official travel; (d) reduced requirements for other services for meeting and workshop facilitation services; and (e) lower requirements for communications and information technology due to lower estimated costs of software licenses and fees, as well as less printing and fewer reproductions and magazine subscriptions for public information and publication services.
Extrabudgetary resources
In 2025, extrabudgetary resources amounting to $447,100 are estimated, as follows:

Voluntary contributions of $311,600, are projected to enhance the Department of Political and Peacebuilding Affairs field capacity to address climate change-related security risks. The project will boost field offices’ abilities to build synergies around climate security and foster opportunities for dialogue.

Cost-recovery resources of $135,500, which are projected to be used to cover the costs of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) in Dakar for utilities and maintenance services and the United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime (UNODC) for rental and utility services under the office-sharing arrangements with the UNOWAS Liaison Cell Office in Nouakchott, Mauritania, and the UNOWAS Liaison Cell Office in Abuja, Nigeria.

In 2026, extrabudgetary resources amounting to $447,100 (comprising voluntary contributions of $311,600 and cost-recovery resources of $135,500) are projected for the above activities aimed at achieving peace and security in West Africa and the Sahel, as well as activities funded from cost recovery.

children.text: A.	Proposed programme plan for 2026 and programme performance in 2024
Overall orientation
Mandates and background

The United Nations Transitional Assistance Mission in Somalia (UNTMIS), formerly the United Nations Assistance Mission in Somalia (UNSOM), is tasked with supporting the Federal Government of Somalia in the attainment of key national priorities while advancing the two-year phased transition of its functions to the Federal Government of Somalia, the United Nations country team and other stakeholders by 31 October 2026.

In its resolution 2753 (2024), the Security Council decided that the United Nations Assistance Mission in Somalia would be called the United Nations Transitional Assistance Mission in Somalia (UNTMIS) and that UNTMIS would continue to implement UNSOM’s mandate and at the same time begin the formal transition of its functions to the Federal Government of Somalia, the United Nations country team and other stakeholders from 1 November 2024. The Council expressed its intention, informed by conditions on the ground, to terminate the mandate of UNTMIS at the end of the anticipated two-phased transition by 31 October 2026.

The Security Council further decided that the first phase of the transition covering seven tasks specified in resolution 2753 (2024) would run from 1 November 2024 until 31 October 2025. During this phase, UNTMIS would continue with the tasks mandated to UNSOM by the Council in resolutions 2158 (2014) and 2592 (2021), and resolution 2705 (2023). The first phase of the transition would be completed by 31 October 2025. The Council further requested the Secretary-General to prepare, in consultation with the Federal Government of Somalia, a road map for delivering the first phase of the transition of the Mission’s tasks to the , the United Nations country team and other stakeholders, including the practical modalities for the transition, such as the reduction of UNTMIS personnel. The Council also requested the Secretary-General to update the Council on the situation regarding Somalia and on progress made in the implementation of the transition plan, through two written reports. The first report, together with the aforementioned road map for the first phase of the transition, was submitted on 28 March 2025. The second report is due by 30 September 2025. Informed by the Secretary-General’s reporting, the Security Council will review the progress of the UNTMIS transition, by 31 October 2025, to support decision-making on timelines for the handover of UNTMIS’s remaining tasks during the second phase of its transition.

In its resolution 2753 (2024), the Security Council requested the Mission to maintain a presence, as appropriate, across Somalia to deliver its transition mandate, in coordination with the Federal Government of Somalia and federal member states, and to ensure strong cooperation with Somalia and the African Union, as the security situation allowed.
Programme of work
Objective

The objective, to which the Mission contributes, is to the advancement of the Federal Government of Somalia’s key national state-building and development priorities, while implementing a phased and gradual transition of its functions to the Federal Government of Somalia, the United Nations country team and other stakeholders through the delivery of its mandate established by the Security Council and in line with the priorities of the Federal Government of Somalia.
Strategy and external factors for 2026
To contribute to the objective, in line with the transition priorities set out in Security Council resolution 2753 (2024) the Mission, will:

Provide support to state-building, including the constitutional review process and efforts to conduct free and fair elections, through inclusive and transparent one-person, one-vote processes, including through capacity building, technical assistance and policy guidance, and facilitation of dialogue to promote reconciliation;
Advance the promotion and protection of human rights, including through institutional and human capacity building, technical assistance and policy guidance;
Provide support to United Nations entities to ensure system-wide implementation of the human rights due diligence policy, where relevant, across United Nations support in country;
Strengthen rule of law, justice and corrections and security sector support, including through capacity building and technical assistance;

Ensure coordination of international donor support, working with bilateral and multilateral partners, including to assist authorities to deliver basic services and community reconciliation, including in areas newly recovered from Al-Shabaab;
Coordinate the United Nations efforts in Somalia;

Coordinate with the African Union Support and Stabilization Mission in Somalia (AUSSOM), with a view to the progressive and phased transfer of these tasks; complete handover of any other outstanding tasks by 31 October 2026.

Facilitate and coordinate with the Federal Government of Somalia and the United Nations country team as well as all relevant stakeholders on finalisation of transition including handover of residual substantive tasks as well as closure of the mission.
The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:

Progress on national priorities on inclusive political processes, security, the rule of law, human rights and economic and social development in line with the objectives in the United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework for the period 2026–2030 aligned to the Somalia’s National Transformation Plan and its Centennial Vision 2060;

Successful transition, closure of the Mission by handover of its remaining tasks to the Federal Government of Somalia, the United Nations country team and other stakeholders retaining the gains made by the Mission since its establishment.

With regard to cooperation with other entities, the Mission will continue its close coordination with AUSSOM. UNTMIS will continue to ensure compliance with the human rights due diligence policy on United Nations support to non-United Nations security forces with regard to United Nations support that may be provided to any non-United Nations entities in Somalia.

With regard to inter-agency coordination and liaison, the Mission will continue collaborating with United Nations agencies, funds and programmes in Somalia, in particular as concerns preparations for the eventual handover of tasks associated with the second phase of the transition. This includes identified mandated activities undertaken through programmes and advancing implementation of the priorities outlined in the United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework in support of the Federal Government of Somalia’s National Transformation Plan and its Centennial Vision 2060.
With regard to the external factors, the overall plan for 2026 is based on the following planning assumptions:
The Federal Government of Somalia and federal member states would have resumed inclusive dialogue and reached political consensus on advancing state-building priorities;
The constitutional review process will have advanced;
The Federal Government of Somalia and federal member states (Puntland and Jubaland) would have resumed dialogue and reached political agreements on advancing state-building priorities.

Somalia will continue to progressively assume responsibility for security, with the Federal Government of Somalia and federal member states making progress towards building able, accountable, acceptable and affordable security institutions as outlined in the Constitution, the national security architecture and the security sector development plan;
Human rights violations by parties to the conflict will remain a concern;

Al-Shabaab will remain the greatest threat to security and stability in Somalia, followed by clan violence and localized disputes, and young Somalis will remain vulnerable to radicalization and recruitment by extremist groups, in particular Al-Shabaab;
Women and girls will continue to be disproportionately affected by inequality, sexual violence, violations of international humanitarian law and violations and abuses of human rights;
The risk of discrimination and exclusion facing minorities, marginalized communities and internally displaced persons will persist;
Freedom of expression and civic space will face challenges, and the risk of human rights violations and protection risks to civilians will persist;
The United Nations presence in Somalia in 2026 will remain dependent on adequate security arrangements acceptable under the established United Nations security management system; and

Availability of sufficient resources and capacities within the identified counterparts in the Federal Government of Somalia, United Nations country team and other stakeholders to enable timely assumption of identified tasks from UNTMIS will remain a concern for successful transition of the Mission.

The Mission integrates a gender perspective into its activities, deliverables and results, as appropriate, including support for the increased protection of women and girls, as well as the full, equal, meaningful and safe participation and representation of women in the political sphere, economic life and reconciliation and peacebuilding efforts.

In line with the United Nations Disability Inclusion Strategy, the Mission, in partnership with the United Nations Support Office in Somalia (UNSOS) has developed a two-year joint action plan for the period 2023–2025, which will conclude in December 2025. In 2026, the Mission will continue to undertake activities that are specifically applicable to them whereas the work that has been led by the Mission will be handed over to the United Nations country team after 31 October 2026.
Programme performance in 2024 – Disability inclusion in Somalia

On 31 July 2024, the House of the People of the Federal Parliament of Somalia approved the Disability Rights Protection Bill, which was later passed by the Upper House of the Federal Parliament of Somalia on 28 October 2024. The Disability Rights Protection Bill was signed into law on 2 December 2024.

From 2023 and throughout 2024, the Mission supported the Federal Ministry of Women and Human Rights Development and the National Disability Agency (NDA) in developing the Disability Rights Protection Bill. The support included technical and legal advice as well as capacity building. During this work, the Mission collaborated closely with the NDA and civil society organizations dedicated to promoting the rights of persons with disabilities. This marks an important milestone in the domestication of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, ratified by Somalia in August 2019.
Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 9).
Table 9 – Performance measure

table_content.text:
The Federal Ministry of Women and Human Rights Development and the National Disability Agency (NDA) developed the Disability Rights Protection Bill, which the Federal Cabinet unanimously approved on 27 July 2023. 

The NDA and organizations of persons with disabilities completed a comprehensive, nationwide disability survey, which informed policymakers about the perceptions and priorities of persons with disabilities and to what extent they participate in public life. 

Support extended to a larger number of organisations of persons with disabilities, such as the Somali Youth Organization for the Visually Impaired.

Somalia made incremental progress towards the adoption of the Disability Rights Protection Bill to ensure the domestication of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. 

The NDA and related organizations working on disability rights undertook efforts to increase their capacity. For example, the Somali National Association of the Deaf was supported on its Somalia-wide consultation on codification of Somali Sign Language, which is currently under review by the Federal Ministry of Education, Culture, and Higher Education. With respect to disability inclusion in disaster preparedness, a group of organizations of persons with disabilities participated in a train the trainers programme and were then supported to train other organizations of persons with disabilities, climate activists and trade unions on disability inclusion in climate justice, resulting in a review of Somalia’s National Determined Contributions.

children.text: Planned results for 2026

Result 1: resolution of outstanding issues of federalization through Federal Government and federal member state dialogue, enabling progress on the constitutional review and other state-building objectives – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

In 2024, the Mission contributed through technical assistance to the constitutional review process and passing of election-enabling legislation, which partially met the planned target of paving way to one person, one vote district, state and national elections as two Jubaland and Puntland states remained outside the process. The Mission supported the convening of three National Consultative Council (NCC) meetings of FGS and FMS leadership to advance national priorities, including through agreement on aspects of the constitutional review process, the fight against Al-Shabaab and proposals for the electoral calendar at the national and subnational levels. The Mission supported the Office of the Prime Minister in ensuring the integration of a gender perspective and inclusion of women into the Council processes. The Mission also supported the capacity-building of parliamentarians to strengthen their participation in the constitutional review process, including the harmonization of federal and state-level constitutions and rules of procedure for the parliamentary process. In addition, the Mission further increased its support for the development of the security sector, including advancing the implementation of the national security architecture, which is central to the federalisation of security.

Until 31 October 2026, the Mission will prioritize its support to national partners in creating an enabling environment for consultations and the operationalization of an inclusive Somali-owned constitutional review process. It will also exercise its good offices and provide technical support to foster political agreements on contentious issues relating to the constitutional framework.

children.text: Result 2: strengthened priority capabilities of Somali rule of law and security institutions at the federal and state levels – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

In 2024, the Mission contributed to strengthening Somali’s rule of law and security institutions at federal and state levels through strategic policy advice, capacity-building initiatives, technical support, and enhanced coordination. The first phase of the Joint Police Program highlighted the need for stronger coordination with national and international partners. To ensure a smooth transition, UN Police will collaborate more closely with UNDP in implementing Phase II.

Until 31 October 2026, the Mission will continue supporting Somali’s rule of law and security institutions through strategic, policy, and technical advice, along with partner coordination. Key priorities include advancing the revised national security architecture, establishing the National Security Council, and implementing the security sector development plan. The Mission will also support legal framework development for the rule of law and security governance, facilitate coordination on force generation, training, and accountability, and contribute to a national maritime security strategy. Additionally, capacity-building initiatives in 2026 will address barriers to women’s professional development in the rule of law sector and promote gender sensitivity among decision-makers. Further efforts will focus on federated policing, justice, and corrections models, promoting judicial independence, civilian oversight, and accountability to enhance access to justice, particularly in fragile areas. Coordination with AUSSOM and national capacity development will also be strengthened. These tasks will progressively be handed over to the appropriate national authorities and to the United Nations country team and international partners by 31 October 2026, according to a transition roadmap to be agreed with the Federal Government of Somalia.

children.text: Result 3: Strengthened Electoral Management and inclusive participation in Somalia’s transition to Universal Suffrage – Proposed programme plan for 2026

In 2026, Somalia will transition to universal suffrage elections at both the Federal and federal member states levels, including presidential and parliamentary elections. The success of these elections depends on the capacity of the National Independent and Boundaries Commission to administer, regulate, and oversee the electoral process effectively.

A robust electoral legal framework, transparent electoral operations and meaningful stakeholder engagement are preconditions to ensure credible, inclusive elections. As Somalia moves forward to conducting universal suffrage elections, strengthening the National Independent and Boundaries Commission will be critical for public trust in the electoral process.
Lessons learned and planned change

Early targeted engagement with policymakers significantly enhances the Mission’s ability to deliver effective technical assistance. This approach raised awareness and deepened knowledge among key counterparts, resulting in a more informed and internationally aligned legal framework. It also highlighted the importance of coordinated stakeholder engagement in ensuring the alignment and adoption of the electoral legal framework, including Temporary Special Measures and the 30 per cent women’s quota.

In applying the lesson, UNTMIS will focus on providing technical support to the National Independent and Boundaries Commission during electoral operations across all stages of the electoral process, based on the Commission’s identified needs. Additionally, the Mission will work and coordinate closely with stakeholders to ensure timely resource mobilizations and maintain coordinated support for Somalia’s transition to direct elections at federal and federal member states levels.

children.text: B. 	Proposed post and non-post resource requirements for 2026
Resource requirements (regular budget)
Table 14 – Financial resources4
(Thousands of United States dollars)
Table 15
Human resources
a One position is funded at 50 per cent and cost-shared with the Development Coordination Office

The proposed resource requirements for 2026 for the Mission amount to $97,616,400 (net of staff assessment) and would provide for: (a) the deployment of 625 United Nations Guard Unit personnel for 10 months and 12 United Nations police personnel for 10 months ($15,009,700); (b) salaries and related costs ($51,714,400) for 157 international posts (1 Under-Secretary-General, 2 Assistant Secretary-General, 7 D-1, 26 P 5, 41 P-4, 30 P-3 and 50 Field Service), 129 national posts (84 National Professional Officer and 45 Local level) and 17 United Nations Volunteers (13 international and 4 national) until 31 October 2026; (b) the deployment of 20 government-provided personnel until 31 October 2026; (c) salaries and related costs for 8 international posts (2 D-1, 1 P-5, 3 P-4, 2 Field Service), which will compose the Mission’s liquidation team for the period from 1 November to 31 December 2026; and (d) operational costs ($30,892,300), comprising the costs for consultants and consulting services ($499,700), official travel ($690,300), facilities and infrastructure ($11,689,300), ground transportation ($1,040,200), air operations ($6,438,900), communications and information technology ($3,628,700), medical ($1,114,200), and other supplies, services and equipment ($5,791,000).

The proposed resources under salaries and other costs also include a provision of $17,464,300 for payments due to staff members at the time of separation from service. The provision comprises estimated termination indemnity ($6,586,300), repatriation grants ($5,042,000), relocation grants ($1,778,000), accrued annual leave for international and national staff ($3,692,600), travel expenses to cover repatriation of international staff ($365,400).

The resources under operational costs also include a provision of $3.8 million as the reimbursement for the logistical support package received from UNSOS, in line with Security Council resolution 2741 (2024), para 5(a), which stipulates that such support package would be on a cost-recovery basis. Based on a comprehensive analysis of workload statistics, specific to different functions in UNSOS, it was estimated that an amount of $3,855,000 (net of staff assessment) should be cost recovered from UNTMIS in 2026 for the logistical support package. This will be duly taken into account in the upcoming proposed budget for UNSOS for the period from 1 July 2026 to 30 June 2027.

Vacancy rates of zero per cent have been applied to the estimates for military contingents; and 41.7 per cent have been applied to the estimates for United Nations police, 17.0 per cent to the estimates for international staff, 15.6 per cent for National Professional Officers, 17.8 per cent for Local level posts based on the actual vacancy rates as at 31 March 2026; 55.0 per cent for government-provided personnel based on the actual average vacancy rate during 2024. Vacancy rates of 27.0 per cent and 75.0 per cent have been applied to the estimates for international United Nations Volunteers and national United Nations Volunteers, respectively, based on the planned deployment.
In preparation for the liquidation, it is proposed to abolish 9 posts (5 P-4, 2 P-2, 2 Field Service) and two international United Nations volunteer positions effective 1 January 2026 as follows:
One post of Corrections Officer (P-4) in the Justice and Corrections Section;
One post of United Nations Police Officer (P-4) in the Police Unit;
One post of Electoral Officer (P-4) in the Integrated Electoral Support Group;
One post of Mission Planning (P-4) Officer in the Regional and Liaison Offices;
One post of Political Affairs Officer (P-4) in the Political Affairs and Mediation Group;
One post of Political Affairs Officer (P-3) in the Political Affairs and Mediation Group;
One post of Electoral Officer (P-3) in the Integrated Electoral Support Group;
Two posts of Administrative Assistants (Field Service) in the Regional and Liaison Offices;
One position of Judicial Affairs Officer (international United Nations Volunteer) in the Justice and Corrections; and
One position of Security Sector Reform Officer (international United Nations Volunteer) in the Security Sector Reform Section.

During the course of 2026, the Mission will progress in its second phase of transition as per the provisions of the resolution 2753 (2024) and it is planned that it will separate the remaining staffing complement except for eight international posts (2 D-1, 1 P-5, 3 P-4, 2 Field Service) which will constitute the UNTMIS liquidation team for the period from 1 November to 31 December 2026. During this period the team will focus on the residual activities related to liaising with the United Nations Agencies, Funds and Programmes on possible challenges and capacity gaps related to the handover of UNTMIS tasks as well as closure of administrative open items in finance and budget in coordination with the United Nations Headquarters.

For military and police personnel and government-provided personnel, 20 government-provided personnel and 12 United Nations police officers are planned to be repatriated, and respective government-provided personnel positions are to be abolished as of 31 October 2026. In addition, the United Nations Guard Unit personnel are also planned to be repatriated as of 31 October 2026.

The decrease in requirements for 2026 compared with the appropriation for 2025 is attributable primarily to the cease of mandated activities and planned repatriation of the all the military and police, the majority of the civilian personnel as well as closure and handover of the Mission’s locations by 31 October 2026. The reduced requirements were partially offset by estimated payments in the amount of $17,464,300 due to staff members at the time of separation from service.

text: 3.	United Nations Regional Centre for Preventive Diplomacy for Central Asia

children.text: A.	Proposed programme plan for 2026 and programme performance in 2024
Overall orientation
Mandates and background

The United Nations Regional Centre for Preventive Diplomacy for Central Asia is responsible for supporting national authorities in identifying and addressing threats to regional peace and security. The open-ended mandate was defined through an exchange of letters between the Secretary-General and the President of the Security Council (S/2007/279 and S/2007/280). The mission plays a central role in preventive diplomacy in Central Asia and provides a platform for regional dialogue on the pressing challenges to security and stability.

The main function of the Centre is to strengthen United Nations capacity for conflict prevention in Central Asia through liaising with the Governments and, with their concurrence, engaging with the parties concerned on promoting preventive diplomacy; monitoring and analysing the situation on the ground, providing the Secretary-General with updates relating to conflict prevention; maintaining contact with regional organizations, encouraging their peacemaking efforts and facilitating coordination and information exchange, with due regard to their specific mandates; providing a political framework and leadership for preventive activities of the United Nations country teams and supporting efforts of the resident coordinators and representatives of the United Nations system, in promoting an integrated approach to preventive diplomacy and humanitarian assistance; and maintaining close contact with the United Nations Assistance Mission in Afghanistan (UNAMA) to ensure a comprehensive analysis of the situation in the wider region.

The Regional Centre’s current work is guided by a five-year programme of action for the period 2021–2025, which was adopted at the annual meeting of deputy ministers for foreign affairs in December 2020. The new programme of action 2026-2030 will be adopted at the end of 2025.
Programme of work
Objective
The objective, to which this mission contributes, is to enhance regional security and stability in Central Asia.
Strategy and external factors for 2026
To contribute to the objective, the mission will:

Carry out good offices functions for preventive diplomacy in Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan, Turkmenistan and Uzbekistan, as well as monitor and analyse regional developments, while maintaining contact with regional organizations and other parts of the United Nations system;

Organize an annual meeting of deputy ministers for foreign affairs of Central Asia and convene expert forums to advise the annual consultative meetings of the Central Asian Heads of State. The Regional Centre will also promote political participation of women through the engagement of senior women political leaders in the Central Asia Women Leaders’ Caucus regional platform;

Promote arrangements on transboundary water management in the region, support initiatives and dialogue on water, energy and environmental and climate cooperation, and help to address challenges relating to transboundary water and climate change;

Implement the joint project with the Office of Counter-Terrorism on the basis of the latest Joint Plan of Action for the implementation of the United Nations Global Counter-Terrorism Strategy in Central Asia. In addition, through the Preventive Diplomacy Academy project, the Centre will continue its efforts to engage young people; and

Support the Central Asian States in addressing emerging threats to security and stability, as well as the other external risk factors, including the complex situation in Afghanistan and developments regarding the construction of the Qush-Tepa Canal.
The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:

Improved regional cooperation in addressing transnational threats of terrorism, violent extremism conducive to terrorism, drug trafficking and organized crime, as well as coping with regional challenges concerning the management of water resources and climate change; and

Political will to sustain the progress of the Governments of the Central Asian States regarding deeper engagements in promoting peace and stability through enhanced cooperation and trust-building in the region, including on high-level platforms such as the consultative meeting of Heads of State.

Regarding cooperation with other entities, the mission maintains contact with the Commonwealth of Independent States, the European Union, the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe and the Shanghai Cooperation Organization, as well as other organizations, such as the International Fund for Saving the Aral Sea (IFAS). The Centre continues exchanges with the Conference on Interaction and Confidence-building Measures in Asia and the Collective Security Treaty Organization on topics of common interest. It cooperates with relevant actors, including international financial institutions such as the World Bank.

With regard to inter-agency coordination, the Centre cooperates closely with the resident coordinators in the five countries, the Development Coordination Office and the entities represented in the United Nations country teams, including UNDP, the UN Women, UNODC, UNOCT, UNESCO, ECE and ESCAP. The mission regularly shares information and coordinates activities with the UNAMA.
With regard to the external factors, the overall plan for 2026 is based on the following planning assumptions:
The continued commitment by five Governments of the region to preventive diplomacy and regional cooperation; and

The five countries of the region continue to monitor developments in Afghanistan and enhance preparedness to potential threats and risks of violent extremism and terrorism, drug trafficking and a potential humanitarian crisis. They continue to provide and advocate for humanitarian assistance to Afghanistan.

The UNRCCA integrates a gender perspective into operational and programmatic activities, deliverables and results, as appropriate. It encourages the countries to ensure gender balance in their delegations and include gender-related issues in the agendas of regional expert-level workshops on preventive diplomacy and confidence-building for the states’ officials.
Programme performance in 2024
Constructive and strengthened relations among the Central Asian States in specific areas

The Regional Centre contributed to regional security and stability through continuous engagement with five Member States on issues of shared concern for the region, including the potential impact of the situation in Afghanistan on water and climate in the region. In 2024, the Counter-Terrorism Early Warning Network for Central Asia was operationalised, contributing to improved exchange of information and coordination among various national and regional entities. The Regional Expert Council on Returnees from the conflict zones was launched. The Central Asia Women Leaders’ Caucus has strengthened its engagement on the situation of women and girls in Afghanistan. The mission continued to promote the Youth, Peace and Security agenda by strengthening the regional Alumni network of the Preventive Diplomacy Academy participants and advancing the Youth-governments dialogue.
Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 16).
Table 16 – Performance measure

table_content.text: Enhanced regional security and stability in Central Asia through more inclusive and open discussions and new initiatives of the countries of the region and the Regional Centre
Strengthened regional cooperation in Central Asia, initiatives promoting peace and trust in the region and more inclusive regional platforms to discuss issues of shared concern

Strengthened regional cooperation in Central Asia, with initiatives that promote peace and trust in the region and more inclusive regional platforms to exchange information and best practices, and the development of recommendations on issues of mutual concern

children.text: Planned result for 2026
Enhanced regional interaction in Central Asia to address current and emerging risks and threats to peace and security – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

In 2024, the mission contributed to enhanced regional security and stability in Central Asia through preventive diplomacy by supporting action to promote trust and cooperation in the region through more inclusive dialogue and partnerships, which met the planned target.
Lessons learned and planned change

The in-person exchanges among counterparts proved to gain meaningful outcomes. In applying this lesson, the mission will strive to conduct meetings, as well as support regional platforms such as the International Fund for Saving the Aral Sea, including participation in various regional events.
Progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see table 17).
Table 17 – Performance measure

table_content.text: Enhanced                                                                                                                                                                            regional security and stability in Central Asia by promoting peace and trust in the region through inclusive and open discussions and new initiatives of the States of the region and the Centre
Enhanced regional interaction in Central Asia to address threats to peace and security through initiatives aimed at promoting peace and trust and inclusive regional platforms

The Regional Centre contributes to an enhancement of regional interaction in Central Asia to address threats to regional peace and security through initiatives aimed at promoting peace and trust and creating inclusive regional platforms
Strengthened regional peace and security in the Central Asian States through enhanced partnerships, dialogue, and trust-building on the basis of the countries’ needs and initiatives

Deeper engagements in the Central Asian States through enhanced partnerships, dialogue, in promoting peace and stability, enhanced cooperation and trust-building in the region, including on high-level platforms such as Central Asian Women Leaders Caucus and Deputy Foreign Ministers meetings

(Thousands of United States dollars)

The proposed resource requirements for 2026 for the Regional Centre amount to $3,458,800 (net of staff assessment) and would provide for salaries and common staff costs $2,711,200 for the continuation of 30 posts (1 Assistant Secretary-General, 1 P-5, 2 P-4, 2 P-3, 2 Field Service, 4 National Professional Officer and 18 Local level), as well as operational costs of $747,600, comprising the costs for consultants and consulting services ($16,800), official travel ($230,100), facilities and infrastructure ($90,800), ground transportation ($29,100), communications and information technology ($211,800), medical supplies ($2,100) and other supplies, services and equipment ($166,900).

For 2026, no change is proposed to the number and levels of the posts. A vacancy rate of zero per cent has been applied to the estimates for international staff and National Professional Officers, based on the actual average vacancy rates in 2024, and vacancy rate of zero per cent has been applied to the estimates for Local level staff taking into account the actual vacancy rates in March 2025.

The decrease in requirements for 2026 compared with the appropriation for 2025 is attributable primarily to: (a) decreased requirements for international staff due to lower estimated common staff costs (estimated common staff costs as a percentage of salary costs of 42.0 per cent compared to 51.5 per cent in the 2025 budget) based on past expenditure; (b) decreased requirements for facilities and infrastructure and communication and information technology, due to lower acquisition of furniture and equipment including communication and information technology equipment. The decreased requirements are offset in part by: (a) increased requirements for national staff owing primarily to higher estimated higher common staff costs for Local level staff (estimated common staff costs as a percentage of salary costs of 37.0 per cent compared to 32.7 per cent in the 2025 budget); and (b) increased requirements under the other supplies, services and equipment class of expenditure for individual contractual services to support mandated priorities in the areas preventive diplomacy related to youth, peace, and security, particularly the Preventive Diplomacy Academy initiative in Central Asia.
Extrabudgetary resources

In 2025, extrabudgetary resources in the amount of $248,000 were projected for the project for Central Asian regional cooperation on transboundary water management, with an updated scope of activities, and for support for the Women Leaders’ Caucus to provide influential leadership on the issues pertaining to gender equality, woman and peace and security and women’s empowerment within and among the countries of the region. Many of the meetings were held in a hybrid format.

In 2026, extrabudgetary resources in the amount of $185,000 are projected, to continue to support the Women Leaders’ Caucus in providing influential leadership on women’s engagement in the countries of the region, as well as activities under the preventive diplomacy academy project, and the Centre’s strategy in support of water, energy and environmental and climate cooperation in the region for the period 2026–2030.
The increase in the estimates projected for 2026 compared with the estimates for 2025 is attributable primarily to the increased travel requirements for in-person and hybrid-format meetings.

text: 4.	United Nations support for the Cameroon-Nigeria Mixed Commission

children.text: A.	Proposed programme plan for 2026 and programme performance in 2024
Overall orientation
Mandates and background

The Cameroon-Nigeria Mixed Commission is responsible for facilitating the implementation of the judgment of the International Court of Justice of 10 October 2002 on the Cameroon-Nigeria boundary and territorial dispute. Its mandate includes supporting the demarcation of the land boundary and the delineation of the maritime boundary; facilitating the withdrawal of troops and transfer of authority in identified areas along the boundary; addressing the situation of the border populations affected by the demarcation process; and making recommendations on confidence-building measures to support them.

The current mandate of the United Nations support team to the Cameroon-Nigeria Mixed Commission derives from the exchange of letters between the Secretary-General and the President of the Security Council (S/2017/78 and S/2017/79) and subsequent exchanges of letters, including, most recently, S/2025/14 and S/2025/15. The mandate is open-ended.
Programme of work
Objective

The objective, to which this mission contributes, is to achieve an orderly and peaceful implementation of the judgment of 10 October 2002 of the International Court of Justice delineating the course of the land and maritime boundary between Cameroon and Nigeria.
Strategy and external factors for 2026
To contribute to the objective, the mission will:
Support the parties in constructing the remaining boundary pillars along the land boundary;
Produce the final maps of the land boundary;
Organize meetings of the drafting committee to finalize a boundary statement at the conclusion of the final mapping;

Regularly monitor the situation of populations affected by the demarcation and promote cross-border development projects as confidence-building measures, including livelihood support, access to potable water, capacity-building, green energy and security;
Continue fundraising efforts among international donors and multilateral partners to finance the confidence-building projects for populations affected by the demarcation; and
Enhance subregional cooperation and good practices in the management of international boundaries by disseminating lessons learned from the Mixed Commission.
The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
Physical demarcation of the land boundary shared by Cameroon and Nigeria through the construction and emplacement of boundary pillars;
Delivery of final maps of the complete land boundary;
Production of a boundary statement recording the field coordinates of the emplaced pillars;
Enhanced support for the demarcation work and improved living conditions of the affected populations; and
Consensus on best practices with respect to border management.

With regard to cooperation with other entities, the mission works with the national authorities of Cameroon and Nigeria to finalize the demarcation process between the two countries. This includes holding meetings, producing final maps, constructing remaining boundary pillars, and preparing a boundary statement.

With regard to inter-agency coordination and liaison, the mission collaborates with the United Nations country teams in Cameroon and Nigeria to jointly develop confidence-building measures based on the needs of communities along the land boundary. This supports peace and sustainable cross-border development. The coordination reduces duplication and streamlines efforts, resulting in a more effective, comprehensive approach to peacebuilding, development, and cooperation. The Mixed Commission Secretariat is hosted within UNOWAS premises in Dakar, which provides administrative and logistical support. The Head of UNOWAS serves as Chair of the Mixed Commission.
With regard to the external factors, the overall plan for 2026 is based on the following planning assumptions:
The two States parties, Cameroon and Nigeria, will continue to adhere to the judgment of the International Court of Justice and the workplan adopted by the Mixed Commission;
Safety, security and climate conditions will permit field operations to continue unimpeded; and
Extrabudgetary resources, including additional voluntary contributions, will continue to be made available for border demarcation, pillar construction and confidence-building initiatives.

The Mixed Commission integrates a gender perspective into its operations, deliverables, and results, as appropriate. Examples include targeting women and youth groups in community development projects related to potable water, employment capacity-building, and access to the electricity network.
Programme performance in 2024
Political commitment to continued dialogue to resolve remaining disagreement areas

In 2024, the mission continued its collaboration with the parties to resolve the three long-standing areas of disagreement.  Bilateral meetings held by the Chair of the Mixed Commission, along with the Extraordinary Mixed Commission session, facilitated focused dialogue. These meetings enabled Cameroon and Nigeria to address the disputed areas pragmatically, prioritizing mutual interests and working toward a resolution beneficial to both countries.  This process led to the adoption of a road map for concluding the demarcation. Consequently, the Project Steering Committee met in Lagos in December to finalize the planning of the last lot of pillar construction and advance the final mapping process. Further, to address confidence building initiatives between the two countries, the mission worked with the national authorities and the United Nations Country Teams in both countries to finalize the needs assessment for the populations affected by the demarcation.
Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 21).
Table 21 – Performance measure

table_content.text: The Sub-Commission on Demarcation conducted a field assessment of the four disputed areas, resulting in an agreement on one of the points of contention.

The Chair of the Cameroon-Nigeria Mixed Commission led consultations to resolve the three remaining boundary disagreements through dialogue, avoiding referral to the International Court of Justice for interpretation of text.
Bilateral meetings and an Extraordinary Mixed Commission session facilitated focused dialogue, leading to the adoption of a road map for completing the demarcation process.

children.text: Planned result for 2026
Result 1: Achievement of consensus between Cameroon and Nigeria – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

In 2024, the mission’s work contributed to the construction of 2,466 pillars, covering 91 per cent of the demarcated boundary, falling short of the target of 2,483 pillars due to fewer pillars needed in that lot. Security concerns in border areas also prevented field assessments, leading to the cancellation of the Sub-Commission on Demarcation meeting to resolve the three remaining areas of disagreement.
Lessons learned and planned change

The Chair’s good offices and engagement with delegation leaders in bilateral meetings facilitated consensus and enabled cooperative resolutions. Applying this lesson, the mission will hold more high-level meetings with State party leaders and technical experts to address the three remaining areas of contention. The Mixed Commission will also continue implementing agreed security protocols, including raising awareness among local authorities and communities, to ensure site access and reduce security risks at pillar emplacement areas.

The decrease in requirements for 2026 compared with the appropriation for 2025 is attributable mainly to: (a) decreased requirements for consultants and consulting services due to reduced travel estimates and scope for civilian observers for observation of the withdrawal and transfer of authority in the Lake Chad area, along the boundary and in the Bakassi peninsula, addressing the situation of affected populations; (b) lower requirement for communication and information technology due to lower acquisition of spare parts and communication and information technology equipment, as well as reduced requirements for the maintenance of equipment; and (c) reduced requirements for air operations in line with historical flight hour utilization rates and lower estimated aviation fuel costs. text: 5.	Office of the United Nations Special Coordinator for Lebanon

children.text: A.	Proposed programme plan for 2026 and programme performance in 2024
Overall orientation
Mandates and background

The mandate of the Office of the United Nations Special Coordinator for Lebanon stems from Security Council resolution 1701 (2006), as well as subsequent decisions of the Council, including S/2007/85 and S/2007/86, S/PRST/2015/7, S/PRST/2016/10 and S/PRST/2025/1. The Special Coordinator is the representative of the Secretary-General to the Government of Lebanon, political parties and the diplomatic community based in Lebanon and provides political guidance and promotes coherence across the Organization’s activities. The Deputy Special Coordinator leads the United Nations country team and humanitarian country team in his capacity as Resident Coordinator/ Humanitarian Coordinator and is responsible for planning and coordinating United Nations humanitarian and development activities in Lebanon.

The Security Council, in its resolution 2749 (2024), expressed support for ongoing diplomatic efforts to de-escalate the situation and restore calm along the Blue Line and demanded the full implementation of resolution 1701 (2006).  In a statement by the President of the Security Council (S/PRST/2025/1) on 16 January 2025, the Council affirmed that the preservation of Lebanon’s stability was essential to regional stability and security. The Council welcomed the cessation of hostilities between Israel and Lebanon of 26 November 2024 (S/2024/870). The Council called on the parties to fully implement the provisions of the cessation of hostilities with the support of the Office of the United Nations Special Coordinator for Lebanon and the United Nations Interim Force in Lebanon, in line with their respective mandates. In the context of UNSCOL’s mandate, these and other core objectives of resolution 1701 (2006) to be furthered will include support to Lebanese state institutions for effective governance, macro-economic stabilization, including with respect to the socioeconomic and humanitarian impact of the latest conflict, disarmament of non-state armed groups, implementation of the arms embargo , and delineating Lebanon’s international borders, both with Israel and Syria.
Programme of work
Objective

The objective, to which this mission contributes, is to prevent and mitigate conflict between Israel and Lebanon and work towards an eventual permanent ceasefire, and to extend and consolidate State authority in support of the territorial integrity, sovereignty and political independence of Lebanon.
Strategy and external factors for 2026
To contribute to the objective, the mission will:

Exercise its good offices between the parties to preserve and facilitate the effective implementation of the November 2024 cessation of hostilities agreement , prevent a relapse into  conflict, and progress the full implementation of resolution 1701 (2006);

Intensify efforts to resolve outstanding obligations of all parties under resolution 1701 (2006) to secure a permanent ceasefire and long-term solution to the conflict, including via the delineation of Lebanon’s international borders;

Advocate for Lebanon’s political leadership to ensure the effective functioning of State institutions, the timely conduct of transparent, inclusive, and credible elections, the adoption of a macroeconomic stabilization programme, and implementation of a comprehensive reform and recovery programme;

Facilitate urgently required recovery and reconstruction imperatives necessitated by the recent conflict and mitigate the impact of the volatility in Syria on the security, stability and refugee situation in Lebanon; and

Support the accelerated extension of State authority across Lebanese territory, intensify engagement with national political stakeholders, as well as with international partners to promote an inclusive dialogue on the disarmament of non-State armed groups, engagement with Syrian authorities on unresolved border issues, to strengthen State security presence along border points and ensure the effective enforcement of the arms embargo.
The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
An enduring cessation of hostilities and a credible monitoring mechanism with the requisite political support in Lebanon and Israel;

Direct or indirect negotiations between Lebanon and Israel to address outstanding obligations under resolution 1701 (2006) towards an eventual permanent ceasefire, including the full withdrawal of the Israel Defense Forces from Lebanese territory;

Effective Lebanese State institutions in place and comprehensive structural reforms initiated to put the country on the path to recovery, uphold its democratic principles, and strengthen good governance;

The State’s effective exercise of authority over all Lebanese territory, including through the strengthened deployment of the Lebanese Armed Forces, and steps taken to secure its borders and other entry points;
Lebanon’s pursuit of a political framework that establishes State monopoly over the possession, transfer and production of arms, delinked from regional conflicts; and
Engagement on the Lebanon-Israel and Lebanon-Syria tracks to delineate the international borders of Lebanon in its entirety, including by addressing the issue of the Shab’a Farms.

With regard to cooperation with other entities, the mission coordinates with the League of Arab States, the European Union and international financial institutions such as the World Bank and IMF to ensure cohesion in political advocacy. The Special Coordinator engages international and regional stakeholders as part of her good offices mandate, to help to build trust and defuse tensions, mobilize broad support for Lebanon’s stability, and promote political and diplomatic processes towards the full implementation of resolution 1701 (2006).

With regard to inter-agency coordination and liaison, the mission cooperates with UNIFIL in the implementation of resolution 1701 (2006) to maintain the cessation of hostilities and to strengthen the extension of State authority across all of Lebanon’s territory. Leveraging the presence of all United Nations entities, the mission brings all available political, security and development tools to bear in a coordinated and harmonized manner in support of Lebanon’s stability. The Mission also contributes to the United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework, and leads its peace and governance results group.
With regard to the external factors, the overall plan for 2026 is based on the following planning assumptions:
International consensus on Lebanon will continue to be challenged;
Political stalemate may hinder effective decision-making, undermine internal dialogue, and economic and governance reforms;
The prolonged socioeconomic crisis, compounded by the impact of the latest conflict, and its humanitarian repercussions will remain sources of instability and social unrest;

Lebanon’s internal stability and security will be increasingly exposed and vulnerable to the volatile regional situation, highlighting the need for bilateral engagement to address potential security concerns;
Internal dynamics in Syria and the maturation of Lebanese-Syrian relations are likely to dictate cross-border movements.

The cessation of hostilities between Lebanon and Israel will remain fragile, underlining the imperative for engagement of the parties in a political process to address the underlying causes of the conflict within the framework of resolution 1701 (2006); and

Extension of State authority in southern Lebanon and along the borders will continue to be affected by political will, other law-and-order requirements, and financial and logistical challenges faced by the State security institutions.

The mission integrates a gender perspective, as appropriate, and is working to enhance women’s political empowerment through a range of initiatives, including legal reforms, special temporary measures, support to women elected and running for office, promotion of an enabling environment, and initiatives in coordination with the United Nations entities and other stakeholders. The mission supports networks engaged in reconciliation, conflict prevention, inclusive community dialogue and mediation. To advance the youth, peace and security agenda, the mission engages youth groups to advocate for their empowerment.
Evaluation activities

An internal evaluation of the United Nations electoral engagement in Lebanon covering the 2020–2023 period conducted jointly with UNDP and completed in 2024 has guided the proposed programme plan for 2026. The results and lessons of the evaluation will result in strengthening the United Nation’s engagement in electoral reform and promoting women’s political participation. Aside from political advocacy, UNSCOL and UNDP are developing ways to intensify engagement with key decision-makers to promote electoral reform, including the adoption of temporary special measures.
Programme performance in 2024
Restored cessation of hostilities between Lebanon and Israel

In 2024, during the severe escalation of hostilities between Hizbullah and Israel, the Special Coordinator engaged key domestic, regional and international actors to restore the cessation of hostilities. Through high-level engagements with relevant stakeholders in Israel and Lebanon, including Hizbullah, and in coordination with international partners, the Special Coordinator exercised her good offices to build common ground and narrow the gaps between the parties. She participated in and supported initiatives, including the United States-France negotiations that eventually secured the cessation of hostilities agreement, and engaged all parties to promote their recommitment to resolution 1701 (2006). The Special Coordinator built political support for a strengthened presence of the Lebanese Armed Forces south of the Litani River, and helped mobilize and coordinate international support to bolster capacities and enhance readiness to deploy.
Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 25).
Table 25 – Performance measure –

table_content.text:
Cessation of hostilities between Lebanon and Israel restored
Israel and Lebanon recommit to resolution 1701 (2006)

children.text: Planned results for 2026
Result 1: Fully functioning State institutions and the exercise of effective State authority throughout Lebanon – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

In 2024, the fulfilment of Lebanon’s constitutional obligations was hampered by the conflict between Hizbullah and Israel and the deepening political polarisation within Lebanon. Following the cessation of hostilities, using its good offices UNSCOL contributed to efforts to break the domestic political deadlock, leading to the election of a President and the designation of a Prime Minister in January 2025.

For 2026, the mission will advocate the strengthening of State institutions, including via institutional revival, economic stabilization, governance reforms, and the conduct of the 2026 elections. The mission will support political processes towards the disarmament of non-state armed groups, and promote the accelerated extension of State authority.
Expected progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 26).

children.text: Result 2: Political and diplomatic efforts to delineate Lebanon’s international borders – Proposed programme plan for 2026

For 2026, the mission will focus on facilitating negotiations that advance the delineation of Lebanon’s borders with Israel and with Syria. To advance long-term solutions to the conflict, the mission will engage domestic, regional and international stakeholders to resolve the contentious border areas, including the Sha’ba Farms.
Lessons learned and planned change

The lesson for UNSCOL was that the incomplete implementation of resolution 1701 (2006) produced a false sense of security. While the November  cessation of hostilities agreement has restored relative stability, conflict triggers remain, leaving Lebanon at risk of renewed violence. In applying the lessons, the mission will prioritize complementarity of a political process to the military-technical process, as defined by the understanding, to create the conditions for a permanent ceasefire and a long-term solution, including the delineation of the border between Lebanon and Israel, and between Lebanon and Syria.
Expected progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 27)
