Consultation, advice and advocacy: consultations with Lebanese and Israeli interlocutors on the implementation of resolution 1701 (2006); consultations with international and regional stakeholders on ensuring Lebanon’s stability; consultations on the economic and governance reform agenda and development priorities; advice on government accountability, governance policy formulation and public administration reforms; advocacy with international partners in support of Lebanon’s efforts for extension of State authority, including strengthened State security agencies; consultations on border delineation and integrated border management on the Lebanon-Syria border; advocacy on key human rights standards and protections that could have an impact on long-term security and stability and the strengthening of human rights institutions in Lebanon; advocacy on the political participation and representation of women and young people; and advocacy with international partners in support of Lebanon for continued donor involvement and resources as Lebanon responds to the presence of Palestine and Syrian refugees, taking into account the needs of refugees and host communities.

children.text: B.	Proposed post and non-post resource requirements for 2026
Resource requirements (regular budget) – Table 29 – Financial resources
(Thousands of United States dollars)
Table 30 – Human resources
a	Post is funded at 50 per cent and cost-shared with the Development Coordination Office.

The proposed resource requirements for 2026 for the mission amount to $11,604,300  (net of staff assessment) and would provide for salaries and common staff costs ($9,924,800) for 21 international posts (1 Under-Secretary-General, 1 Assistant Secretary-General, 1 D-1, 2 P-5, 7 P-4, 1 P-3, 2 P-2 and 6 Field Service) and 67 national posts (5 National Professional Officer and 62 Local level), as well as operational costs ($1,679,500 ), comprising the costs for official travel ($167,600), facilities and infrastructure ($871,300), ground transportation ($77,900), communications and information technology ($453,300), medical ($6,000) and other supplies, services and equipment ($103,400).
In 2026, the proposed staffing complement includes the establishment of 5 posts, as follows:
Immediate Office of the Special Coordinator

Establishment of one post of Field Language Assistant (Local level) to provide essential support during meetings and communications with Arabic-speaking interlocutors in Lebanon, Syria, and key Arab capitals and for the translation of official documents. The mission has no capacity for interpretation/simultaneous translation from Arabic to English to support the Special Coordinator in her meetings;
Public Information Unit

Establishment of one post of Chief Public Information Officer and Spokesperson (P-4) to improve awareness of the mandate and role of the Special Coordinator, enhance media communications and monitoring capability, and generally underpin the Special Coordinator’s quiet diplomacy in pursuit of the mandate objectives. The enhanced political and diplomatic engagement in Lebanon and Israel by the Special Coordinator will require effective media communications and outreach in Lebanon and Israel;

Establishment of one post of Public Information Assistant (Local level) to update the mission leadership on critical developments or events in Lebanon, Israel and the region, monitor including through processing regional and local media processing local and report on hate speech , mis-disinformation and disinformation, and to support the Mission’s public information campaigns, outreach and other events, as well as multi-media materials;
Political Affairs Section

Establishment of one post of Associate Political Affairs Officer (P-2) to assist the Special Coordinator’s efforts in pursuing a multipronged political approach to accelerate the implementation of resolution 1701 (2006). The incumbent will be responsible for strengthening reporting and analytical capacity, supporting the development of mechanisms for data analytics to maintain and manage data sets relevant to the implementation of resolution 1701 (2006), including via contributions to the development of roadmaps and relevant research, as well as coordination of new political initiatives to advance mandate implementation.
Coordination Unit

Establishment of one post of Associate Coordination Officer (P-2), under the guidance of the Deputy Special Coordinator for Lebanon, to develop concise fact sheets and briefing packages,  provide analytical documents, reports on discussions and tracking progress, support the development of strategies and initiatives that promote cross-pillar cooperation and strategy coherence with agencies, support in information flow between the mission and other stakeholders, most notably the humanitarian pillar in real-time within a crisis setting.

A vacancy rate of 11.1 per cent has been applied to the estimates for international staff on the basis of the actual average vacancy rates in 2024. A vacancy rate of zero per cent has been applied to the estimates for National Professional Officer posts, and a vacancy rate of 5.0 per cent has been applied to the estimates for Local level posts, both on the basis of the actual vacancy rates in March 2025. A vacancy rate of 50 per cent has been applied to the five posts proposed for establishment.

The increase in requirements for 2026 compared with the appropriation for 2025 is attributable mainly to: (a) the proposed establishment of five posts (1 P-4, 2 P-2 and 2 Local level); (b) increased requirements for national staff owing to the application of a lower vacancy rate of 5.0 per cent compared to the rate of 6.7 per cent approved for 2025; (c) increased requirements for facilities and infrastructure for the replacement of prefabricated and security equipment that are beyond their useful life and increased requirements for rental costs and small alternation and renovation projects to meet the growing operational demands and enhance working environment; (d) increased requirements for communication and information technology to replace critical, obsolete equipment and assets that have exceeded their life expectancy, as well as additional resources for public information services as part of a broader strategy to promote the implementation of resolution 1701 (2006); and (e) increased requirements under other supplies, services and equipment due to higher estimated freight costs for the equipment to be acquired. The increased requirements were offset in part by lower requirements for international staff due to the application of revised salary rates; and the non-provisioning of resources for consultants and consulting services.

text: 6.	United Nations Regional Office for Central Africa

children.text: A.	Proposed programme plan for 2026 and programme performance in 2024
Overall orientation
Mandates and background

UNOCA is responsible for the prevention of conflicts and the consolidation of peace and security in Central Africa. The mandate derives from an exchange of letters between the Secretary-General and the President of the Security Council (S/2009/697 and S/2010/457). In another exchange of letters (S/2024/648 and S/2024/649), the mandate was extended until 31 August 2027.

The mandate for 2024–2027 encompasses four objectives, namely: (a) monitor political and security developments in Central Africa and carry out good offices on behalf of the Secretary-General in order to prevent and resolve conflicts, to help to sustain peace and to advise the Secretary-General and United Nations entities in the region on sustaining peace issues in Central Africa; (b) enhance subregional capacities for conflict prevention and mediation in countries of the subregion, with due attention given to the principles of the Charter of the United Nations, including human rights and gender dimensions; (c) support and enhance United Nations efforts in the subregion, as well as regional and subregional initiatives on peace and security, including from human rights and gender perspectives; and (d) enhance coherence and coordination in the work of the United Nations in the subregion on peace and security.
The mission serves as the secretariat of the United Nations Standing Advisory Committee on Security Questions in Central Africa.
Programme of work
Objective
The objective, to which this mission contributes, is to prevent conflict and consolidate peace and security in the Central Africa subregion.
Strategy and external factors for 2026
To contribute to the objective, the mission will:

Engage in good offices activities to help countries to prevent political crises and election-related violence and peacefully resolve conflicts and crises stemming from political processes, including political transitions, and promote inclusive, peaceful and credible elections;

Leverage its partnership with subregional organizations, especially the Economic Community of Central African States (ECCAS) in conflict prevention, mediation and early warning, ensuring the participation of women, young people and other actors in inclusive peacebuilding and sustaining peace efforts, including the implementation of the regional strategy on hate speech, and addressing the adverse effects of climate change on peace and security;

Address cross-regional peace and security challenges, including farmer-herder dynamics, the crisis in the Lake Chad Basin and maritime piracy in the Gulf of Guinea, in close coordination with United Nations entities in Central and West Africa;

Carry out regular early warning analysis to inform preventive diplomacy and good offices efforts for peace and security in Central Africa, and mobilize support for preventive diplomacy, in collaboration with ECCAS and United Nations entities;

Enhance the coherence of the work of the United Nations on peace and security issues in Central Africa through regular consultations with relevant United Nations entities in the subregion, coordinate the efforts of United Nations entities geared towards the implementation of the regional conflict prevention framework and in line with commitments of the Pact for the Future, and support the country teams in adopting and/or rolling out national sustaining peace strategies aligned with the framework; and

Support the regular ministerial meetings of United Nations Standing Advisory Committee on Security Questions in Central Africa as a platform for confidence-building between Member States to discuss threats and challenges to regional peace and security, with a view to preventing or addressing conflicts, crises or inter-State tensions.
The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
Peaceful and credible electoral processes in the subregion, with relevant prevention mechanisms in place for potential election-related violence;

Prevention and mitigation of election-related violence, as well as the initiation or continuation of inclusive political dialogue processes, assisted by joint early-warning and good offices by the Mission and ECCAS in countries holding elections, facing a political crisis or undergoing a political transition;
Progress made by ECCAS towards the adoption of a regional humanitarian strategy for Central Africa and the set-up of the ECCAS parliament;

The United Nations Standing Advisory Committee on Security Questions in Central Africa is contributing to reinforced cooperation and coordination among ECCAS Member States, regional organisations and other key stakeholders of the subregion.

A shared understanding of key peace and security challenges and priorities among United Nations entities in Central Africa, integrating emerging drivers of conflicts, including the impact of climate change and environmental degradation;
Enhanced coordination of United Nations efforts in support of regional and subregional initiatives on peace and security and governance; and

Improved interregional coordination of efforts between Central and West Africa on: maritime security in the Gulf of Guinea; impact of climate change on peace and security; farmer-herder dynamics; and the crisis in the Lake Chad Basin region.

With regard to inter-agency coordination and liaison, the mission works closely with the Office of the Special Envoy of the Secretary-General for the Great Lakes Region, UNOWAS, MINUSCA, MONUSCO and other relevant United Nations entities with respect to cross-border and transregional challenges to peace and security, in order to avoid duplication and ensure coherence and enhance synergies. Country-specific early warning and good offices activities are carried out in close coordination with the resident coordinators concerned.
With regard to external factors, the overall plan for 2026 is based on the following planning assumptions:
ECCAS institutional reform becomes increasingly more operational, with all peace and security institutions and mechanisms established and provided with adequate resources for their functioning;

UNOCA and ECCAS maintain or strengthen their cooperation and regular consultations, and adopt and roll out a joint plan of action, within the framework of a new memorandum of understanding between ECCAS and the United Nations on peace and security issues;

ECCAS member States remain committed to establishing a regional governance framework, work towards the adoption and implementation of regional governance standards and mechanisms and solicit or accept the support of UNOCA and regional and international partners;

The elections scheduled in the countries of the region, including in the countries undergoing political transitions, are held according to the constitutional and legal time frames or agreed-upon transitional timelines and the countries concerned accept the political engagement of UNOCA and ECCAS to defuse tensions, prevent election-related violence and resolve election-related crises;

ECCAS and its member States show a commitment to the involvement of civil society actors, including the regional Coalition of Civil Society Organizations for Peace and Conflict Prevention in Central Africa, the Coalition of Youth, Peace and Security in Central Africa  and women’s organizations, in the activities of ECCAS in the realm of peace and security, including early warning, conflict prevention and peacebuilding. The Coalition becomes fully operational, with adequate human resources, and is supported by ECCAS member States and partners; and

ECCAS member States develop, adopt and begin implementation of a conflict-sensitive regional strategy on climate change and resilient development and regional regulation on pastoralism and transhumance in Central Africa to address the impacts of climate change on peace and security, while strengthening national and local mechanisms to prevent and peacefully resolve farmer-herder conflicts, and promote peaceful cross-border transhumance.

The mission integrates a gender perspective into its operational activities, deliverables and results, as appropriate, including support for the implementation of the regional action plan on Security Council resolution 1325 (2000) and the adoption and rolling out of national action plans. It continues its advocacy for the reinforcement of the role of women in conflict prevention and sustaining peace, as well as adequate representation of women in decision-making positions at both the national and regional levels. It works with other relevant United Nations entities and external partners to reinforce the capacities of women in decision-making and in mediation. It will continue supporting the operationalization and build the capacity of the ECCAS network of women mediators established in December 2021 and endorsed by the Heads of State in January 2022.

In line with the United Nations Disability Inclusion Strategy, the mission advocates for political and electoral processes in the region to be disability-sensitive, by encouraging Member States to take appropriate measures to facilitate the participation of persons with disabilities. The mission also encourages and supports experience-sharing between the States of the region on disability inclusion, thus facilitating the adoption of measures that take into consideration the specificities of the regional and national contexts.
Programme performance in 2024
Reduced tensions in electoral contexts

In 2024, through good offices of the Special Representative of the Secretary-General, including the joint mission carried out with the President of the ECCAS Commission and the Special Envoy of the ECCAS facilitator for the transition in Chad, UNOCA encouraged political dialogue in Chad to create conditions for inclusive, peaceful and credible polls. The organization of the presidential election in May 2024 and legislative, provincial and local elections in December 2024 marked important steps towards the restoration of a constitutional order in Chad. Furthermore, UNOCA implemented projects to facilitate the effective participation of women and youth in the National Dialogue and the upcoming elections in Gabon in 2025.
Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 31).
Table 31 – Performance measure

table_content.text: Elections in Central Africa generally peaceful, with no or low level of violence
Political transition in Chad advanced in an environment of relative calm including through the implementation of the Doha Peace Agreement.

Chad peacefully concluded its political transition, with the organizations of legislative, provincial and local elections. 
Gabon’s transition advanced in a peaceful and inclusive manner, in line with the defined timeline.

children.text: Planned result for 2026
Result: Strengthened regional capacities for conflict prevention and mediation in Central Africa – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

In 2024, the mission’s work contributed to strengthening of the capacities of Member States in Central Africa, including through the implementation of the Kigali Declaration on the prevention and combating of unconstitutional changes in Central Africa and continued engagement with civil society organizations. The regional conference on unconstitutional changes of government in Central Africa, organized by UNOCA and the Government of São Tomé and Príncipe, resulted in recommendations on addressing the root causes of unconstitutional changes of government in the region. Additionally, joint efforts have been made in partnership with local, regional and international stakeholders, with particular attention to ensure full, equal and meaningful participation of women and youth.
Lessons learned and planned change

A lesson for the mission was that coordination and cooperation with relevant stakeholders, particularly with regional and subregional organizations, are essential for more effective results. In applying the lesson, UNOCA plans to continue working with ECCAS and its Member States, as well as UN presences and country teams in the region and international and national stakeholders to prevent conflict and consolidate peace through promotion of good governance, taking into account the role of women and youth.
Progress towards the objective and the target for 2025 are presented in the performance measure below (see table 32).
Table 32 – Performance measure

table_content.text: Recommendations on strengthening governance are concretized in line with the Kigali Declaration adopted by the United Nations Standing Advisory Committee on Security Questions in Central Africa
Progress is achieved towards the development of a regional protocol on good governance
Regional protocol on good governance is developed in close consultation with regional stakeholders

Resource requirements (regular budget) – Table 34 – Financial resources
(Thousands of United States dollars)
Table 35 – Human resources

The proposed resource requirements for 2026 for the mission amount to $8,329,200 (net of staff assessment) and would provide for salaries and common staff costs ($6,759,100) for the continuation of 33 international posts (1 Under-Secretary-General, 2 D-1, 5 P-5, 12 P-4, 6 P-3 and 7 Field Service), 16 national posts (4 National Professional Officer and 12 Local level) and one national United Nations Volunteer, as well as operational costs ($1,570,100), comprising the costs for consultants ($9,800), official travel ($535,900), facilities and infrastructure ($198,600), ground transportation ($63,000), air operations ($132,200), communications and information technology ($503,600) and other supplies, services and equipment ($127,000).

A vacancy rate of 12.1 per cent has been applied to the estimates for international staff on the basis of the actual vacancy rate as of March 2025. Vacancy rates of 25.0 per cent for National Professional Officer posts, 16.7 per cent for Local level posts and zero per cent for national United Nations Volunteers have been applied to the estimates based on the actual average vacancy rates in 2024.

The increase in requirements for 2026 compared with the appropriation for 2025 is attributable mainly to: (a) increased requirements under international staff due to the application of a lower vacancy rate of 12.1 per cent compared to the rate of 20.2 per cent in the approved budget for 2025; and (b) increased requirements for Local level staff owing primarily to the application of the most recent salary scale. The increased requirements are offset in part by reduced requirements for air operations in line with historical flight hour utilization rates, and the non-provisioning of resources for individual contractual services.
Extrabudgetary resources

In 2025, extrabudgetary resources in the amount of $713,500 are projected to be used to continue to support regional capacities to prevent, mitigate and resolve election-related crises and violence in the Central Africa subregion, including through the strengthening of electoral governance and support for the adoption of a regional protocol on democratic elections, and the continuation of one position of Political Affairs Officer (P-4), and establishment of one Junior Professional Officer/Associate Expert in Political Affairs.
In 2026, extrabudgetary resources in the amount of $400,000 are projected to be utilised to support the continuation of the above-mentioned projects.

text: 7.	United Nations Support Mission in Libya

children.text: A.	Proposed programme plan for 2026 and programme performance in 2024
Overall orientation
Mandates and background

The United Nations Support Mission in Libya (UNSMIL) is an integrated special political mission established by the Security Council in its resolution 2009 (2011). The Mission is mandated to support the country’s transition and post-conflict efforts, including through an inclusive national dialogue and a constitution-drafting process. Following the signing of a nationwide ceasefire agreement on 23 October 2020 that ended the armed conflict that began in April 2019, the Council, in its resolution 2570 (2021), further mandated UNSMIL to provide support to the 5+5 Joint Military Commission and the Libyan-led and Libyan-owned ceasefire monitoring mechanism.

On 24 January 2025, the Secretary-General appointed Ms. Hanna Serwaa Tetteh of Ghana as his Special Representative for Libya and Head of UNSMIL. The Mission’s mandate was extended until 31 October 2025 through resolution 2755 (2024), in which the Council requested the Secretary-General to submit a strategic review of UNSMIL to the Council no later than 30 September 2025.

On 4 February, UNSMIL announced the establishment of an advisory committee of 20 Libyan independent experts (7 women, 13 men) as part of a multi-track initiative in the Libyan-led and Libyan-owned political process facilitated by the United Nations. The role of the committee is to develop technically sound and politically viable proposals for resolving outstanding contentious issues to enable the holding of elections, building on the existing Libyan framework and laws, submitted to UNSMIL for consideration for the subsequent phase of the political process. In response to the violent clashes that erupted in Tripoli on 12 May, the Mission, together with the Presidency Council, launched a truce committee on 18 May to stabilize the situation and advance security arrangements in the capital.
Programme of work
Objective

The objective, to which this Mission contributes, is to support an inclusive Libyan-led political process and rights-based national reconciliation, conflict prevention and peacebuilding efforts; strengthen rule of law institutions, transitional justice processes and State-building efforts to optimize readiness for planning and implementing credible, transparent and inclusive elections; to advance human rights, gender equality and women and youth political participation; to support for the reform of the security sector, disarmament, demobilization and reintegration efforts and further the implementation of the October 2020 ceasefire agreement.
Strategy and external factors for 2026
To contribute to the objective, the Mission will:

Provide mediation and good offices to support a Libyan-led, Libyan-owned political process facilitated by the United Nations and supported by international partners, with a focus on addressing contested political issues, enabling inclusive national presidential and parliamentary elections and fostering good governance. The Mission will continue to engage with a wide spectrum of Libyan stakeholders at all levels, particularly women and youth, to amplify their participation in the democratic transition and reconciliation processes;
Provide technical assistance to the High National Elections Commission for conducting transparent and inclusive national and municipal elections;

Support inclusive, victim-centred and rights-based national reconciliation processes based on transitional justice principles through capacity-building for reconciliation bodies and facilitating dialogue among diverse Libyan actors, including civil society, women and youth;
Strengthen the rule of law and accountability by supporting Libya’s judiciary and prosecutorial systems, including their critical role in ensuring justice for all Libyans;

Promote and protect human rights by monitoring, reporting and addressing violations, with a focus on sexual violence in conflict and violations against vulnerable groups, and by ensuring civic space for political participation;

Advance security sector reform by engaging legislative bodies to review national security legislation and supporting trust-building measures for the reunification of security and military institutions under civilian oversight, while establishing enhanced security coordination mechanisms;

Facilitate disarmament, demobilization and reintegration through community violence reduction initiatives, national coordination and civil society engagement, technical training and operational planning, including support for mine action coordination and weapon and ammunition management;

Support the 5+5 Joint Military Commission and its subcommittees in implementing the ceasefire agreement, including the withdrawal of foreign forces, foreign fighters and mercenaries and by engaging women, youth and civil society organizations on sustaining and strengthening the ceasefire agreement;

Support economic policy reform, in close cooperation with Member States and international financial institutions, including reunification and reform of the country’s banking system, a decentralization policy and the establishment of an inclusive and unified oversight mechanism that ensures transparent, equitable and accountable management of revenue across the country and distribution of national resources;

Advance the Women, Peace, and Security (WPS) and agenda, by expanding existing training programmes to build leadership capacity and promoting their meaningful participation in political and peacebuilding processes;
Engage with neighbouring countries, including sub-Saharan African countries, to ensure that their views and concerns are taken into consideration.
The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:

An inclusive Libyan-led and Libyan-owned political process that leads to elected, unified, functional and representative government institutions, including economic institutions, contributing to political and economic stability and rights-based reconciliation;
Enhanced accountability of institutions, promotion of the rule of law throughout the country, and reconciliation and transitional justice processes promoting and protecting human rights;

Unified security sector institutions operating under civilian oversight, including professional, unified and accountable defence and security forces and full implementation of the provisions of the ceasefire agreement, including the withdrawal of foreign fighters, foreign forces and mercenaries.

The Mission cooperates with relevant local, national, regional and international partners and regional organizations, including the African Union, League of Arab States, and European Union and the United Nations-African Union-European Union quartet.

The Mission and the United Nations country team have taken steps towards enhancing integration, including through the United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework (2023-2026) and will continue to operationalize the Secretary-General’s focus on the humanitarian-development-peace nexus to facilitate long-term peace, security and sustainable development, in order to enhance the impact of United Nations interventions in support of all people in Libya.
With regard to the external factors, the overall plan for 2026 is based on the following planning assumptions:

The Libyan Political Agreement of December 2015, Security Council resolution 2510 (2020), by which the Council endorsed the conclusions of the Berlin Conference on Libya, the October 2020 ceasefire agreement, relevant provisions of the Libyan Political Dialogue Forum Tunis road map and accompanying outputs, and resolutions5, as well as the comprehensive approach to enabling elections, will remain the guiding framework for United Nations support in Libya. The Libyan-led multitrack political process, facilitated by the United Nations, will establish the roadmap for elections and address contested political issues;

The economic sector will continue to suffer from a lack of independent oversight and transparent management of public funds, while efforts to reunify the Central Bank will continue as part of the implementation of the road map and independent audit recommendations for reunification;

The Libyan ceasefire agreement of October 2020, including the withdrawal of foreign forces, foreign fighters and mercenaries, will continue to be implemented, and consensus will be reached among relevant security and political actors in Libya on reforming and unifying security institutions and creating conditions conducive to the launch of a disarmament, demobilization and reintegration process;

The human rights situation in Libya will remain challenging, especially with respect to enhancing the rule of law and protecting and promoting civic space for all people in Libya to exercise their fundamental rights, in particular civil and political rights. Marginalization and underrepresentation of women in political and reconciliation processes will continue to pose a challenge to peacebuilding;

Institutional weaknesses and divisions among the country’s security actors will continue to enable violent extremist organizations to benefit from power vacuum and ungoverned spaces, thus inadvertently fostering an environment conducive to terrorism;

The security situation will remain fragile due to proliferation of weapons and armed actors, lack of unified security institutions, competition between armed actors, predatory economy, as well as the continued presence of smuggling and trafficking networks;

The overall humanitarian situation will continue to improve in line with security stabilization, with a steady decrease in the number of people needing humanitarian assistance and internally displaced persons. Meanwhile, the continued conflict in Sudan will require increased support for protection needs of Sudanese refugees, as well as other refugees, asylum seekers and migrants; and

Strategic partnerships will continue among the international community, including regional organizations and the United Nations, in support of a Libyan-led and Libyan-owned political process adhering to the United Nations sanctions regime.

The Mission integrates a gender perspective into its operational activities, deliverables, and results, as appropriate. From 2026 onward, the Mission will implement a renewed three-year action plan, “Inclusive Mediation and Peacebuilding Processes in Libya: Protection and Participation of Women (2026–2028)”. As part of the plan, the Mission will promote women’s participation in political and reconciliation processes and their representation in government institutions. To safeguard equal rights and opportunities for women, the Mission and the United Nations country team jointly promote women’s equal enjoyment of political, civil, economic and social rights through technical assistance to national institutions and civil society actors; advocacy for gender-responsive legislation and policies that protect women from violence; and measures to address gaps in basic services, particularly for displaced, migrant, and refugee women and girls. The Mission will support prevention and protection efforts in Libya, including through capacity-building for relevant institutions.
Evaluation activities

In 2024, the Mission conducted a comprehensive staffing review exercise, providing an assessment of the organizational capacity and Mission structures and recommendations to enhance effectiveness and efficiency.  During the conduct of the review, the Security Council, in its resolution 2755 (2024), requested the Secretary-General to submit a strategic review no later than 30 September 2025, which includes an assessment and recommendations for increasing the efficiency and effectiveness of UNSMIL’s overall structure, including the objectives of UNSMIL. In view of the pending strategic review, the results of the concluded staffing review exercise would be reviewed against the outcome of strategic review, and as such are not reflected in the proposed programme plan for 2026.
In 2025, in addition to the strategic review mandated by the Council, UNSMIL plans to conduct a lesson’s learned exercise for the upcoming municipal council elections.
Programme performance in 2024
Strengthened rule of law institutions and transitional justice process protecting the rights of all people in Libya

In 2024, the Mission provided technical assistance to the Presidential Council to finalize a draft law on national reconciliation which would lay the basis of a comprehensive and victims-centred transitional justice process. In partnership with the African Union, supported by the Chairs of the Berlin International Humanitarian Law/ Human Rights Working Group and in line with the provisions of the Libyan Political Dialogue Forum Roadmap, the Mission enabled consensus on a draft law that protects the independence of future transitional justice mechanisms. The Mission consistently engaged with victims and families of missing persons to document cases for future accountability.
Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 36 below).
Table 36 – Performance measure

table_content.text:
Draft law on combating violence against women to the legislative bodies was agreed
The Monitoring, Analysis and Reporting Arrangement on conflict-related sexual violence was established
A high-level committee on arbitrary detention, representing the Attorney General, the military prosecution, the police, and intelligence and judicial institutions continued its work
Human rights defenders and civil society actors in Libya are increasingly able to operate in a safer and more supportive environment

The signing of a statement in favour of the adoption of the draft law by members of the legislative committee and women’s block of the House of Representatives highlighted UNSMIL’s mobilization of further support. However, the House of Representatives did not discuss the proposed draft law on the protection of women against violence, nor did it adopt a comprehensive law on transitional justice
Members of the public prosecution were trained as part of efforts to strengthen the rule of law institutions to investigate, prosecute, adjudicate and prevent abuses and violations of human rights
Members of civil society organizations and women human rights defenders were trained on collecting data on conflict-related sexual violence and monitoring of violations of human rights

A draft of the associations law was agreed by civil society organizations in 2024 and was reviewed by the Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights and a gender consultant to ensure a comprehensive gender perspective
A joint consultation forum was established as part of the Monitoring, Analysis and Reporting Arrangement on conflict-related sexual violence 
Women Human Rights’ Defenders in Libya are gaining stronger safeguards as the zero draft of the protection strategy nears completion
A draft law on national reconciliation was elaborated by Presidential Council through extensive consultations with victims’ groups, supported by UNSMIL, and through UNSMIL-facilitated consensus with the parliament, although the law remains to be adopted

children.text: Result 2: A comprehensive roadmap for holding national elections, towards the establishment of unified, elected, legitimate, inclusive and functional government institutions contributing to political stability and reconciliation – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

171.	In 2024, UNSMIL facilitated the resolution of the Central Bank of Libya leadership crisis and launched a United Nations-facilitated and Libyan-owned multitrack political process. UNSMIL provided technical assistance to the High National Election Commission in the holding of peaceful elections in 58 municipalities.

172.	In 2026, UNSMIL will address unresolved electoral framework issues and propose a viable roadmap for elections. UNSMIL will continue advancing a structured dialogue to consolidate consensus around a unified national vision for the future of the country. The Mission plans to implement quick-impact projects to enhance confidence in its mandate in supporting the political process, reconciliation and prevention of intra- and inter-community violence, while ensuring tangible benefits for local communities. The projects will focus, among others, on women empowerment and income generation.

children.text: Result 3: establishment of a comprehensive legal framework for a victim-centred transitional justice and reconciliation process – Proposed programme plan for 2026

In 2026, the Mission will support Libyan stakeholders in developing and implementing a Charter of Rights, reinforcing existing legal frameworks, integrating human rights in the political agreement and facilitating reconciliation and transitional justice processes and fostering peace and social cohesion. In collaboration with political actors, civil society organizations, victims’ groups and the African Union, UNSMIL will advocate for the adoption of key legislative frameworks, including the National Reconciliation Law and the Law on the Protection of Women from Violence, as well as a new legislation on the rights of missing persons.
Lessons learned and planned change

The lesson learned for the Mission was that inclusive participation by Libya’s diverse political, social and geographic components, including women and youth and ethnic minorities and victim communities, is critical to sustainable peace and stability. In applying this lesson, the Mission will strengthen engagement with underrepresented groups and integrate broader social, economic and regional dynamics into its reconciliation and peacebuilding efforts.
Progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see table 39).
Table 39 – Performance measure

table_content.text: Effective reparations and accountability mechanisms are in place to address past grievances and promote justice

Operationalization of an independent Truth and Reconciliation Commission mandated to investigate on past violations and provide justice and reparations to victims while guaranteeing non-recurrence of violations

The proposed resource requirements for 2026 for UNSMIL amount to $90,432,200 (net of staff assessment) and would provide for the deployment of 233 United Nations Guard Unit personnel ($6,609,000), salaries and related costs ($47,390,000) for the deployment of 276 international posts and positions (1 Under-Secretary-General, 2 Assistant Secretary-General, 7 D-1, 18 P-5, 46 P-4, 46 P-3, 2 P-2, 154 Field Service) and 139 national posts and positions (20 National Professional Officers, 1 General Service and 118 Local level), 6 international United Nations Volunteers and 7 government-provided personnel, as well as operational costs ($36,433,200) comprising the costs for consultants and consulting services ($82,600), official travel ($970,000), facilities and infrastructure ($26,778,600), ground transportation ($203,200), air operations ($3,937,800), communications and information technology ($2,301,900), medical ($444,200) other supplies, services and equipment ($1,664,900), and quick-impact projects (50,000).

A vacancy rate of 22.9 per cent has been applied to the estimates for international staff on the basis of the actual average vacancy rate in 2024. Vacancy rates of 15.0 and 26.1 per cent have been applied for National Professional Officers and General Service categories staff, respectively, on the basis of the actual vacancy rates in March 2025. A vacancy rate of 25.0 per cent has been applied to the estimates for United Nations Volunteer positions and a vacancy rate of 53.6 per cent has been applied to the estimates for government-provided personnel on the basis of the actual vacancy rates in March 2025. The estimates for United Nations Guard Unit personnel are based on the actual deployment in March 2025.
UNSMIL Comprehensive Staffing Review

The Mission conducted a comprehensive staffing review from September 2024 to March 2025. It was led by a Task Force in coordination with United Nations Headquarters and in consultation with the Field Staff Union. The review aimed to align staffing resources with mandate priorities and operational needs, and to assess the Mission support structure in line with the Department for Operational Support guidelines on Mission Support Structure for Small Missions. By its resolution 2755 (2024), the Council requested the Secretary-General to submit a strategic review of UNSMIL to the Council no later than 30 September 2025, including recommendations for increasing the efficiency and effectiveness of UNSMIL’s overall structure, including the objectives of UNSMIL.  As the strategic review will be finalized after the 2026 proposed programme budget, the outcome of the staffing review is not reflected in the current proposed budget for 2026. The Mission awaits the outcome of the strategic review to ensure alignment with the Mission’s long-term strategic direction and future Security Council decisions.

As at 31 March 2025, the Mission had 52 long-vacant posts, of which 32 were posts approved for establishment at the end of March 2022 in the context of the 2022 revised estimates to support the ceasefire monitoring mandate (see A/76/6(Sect.3)/Add.8). Of the 52 long-vacant posts, the comprehensive staffing review recommended post actions for 39 posts. In view of the pending strategic review, as well as the slow pace of operationalization of the 2020 ceasefire agreement, a vacancy rate of 100 per cent has been applied in the current proposed budget to the 32 posts vacant for more than 3 yea	The Mission’s approved 2025 staffing complement includes eight general temporary assistance positions. It is proposed that these positions be continued in 2026, as detailed below:
Office of the Deputy Special Representative of the Secretary-General, Political

The UNSMIL Mine Action Unit supports the delivery of the Mission’s mine action mandate in line with Security Council resolution 2755 (2024) by providing technical expertise and support to the Libyan security institutions and the ceasefire mechanisms on mine action and weapons and ammunition management, and representing the Mission in relationship with relevant national mine action stakeholders and the United Nations country team. The temporary assistance position of Chief of Section, Programme Management (P-5), was established on 1 January 2022 in response to a recommendation from the Board of Auditors to improve the Secretariat leadership of UNSMIL mine action programme. Seven other temporary assistance positions were established under the UNSMIL mine action programme as of 1 January 2025 as part of the transition of mine action delivery from implementation in partnership with UNOPS to direct Secretariat delivery. These positions include three Programme Management Officers (P-4), one Programme Management Officer (P-3), one Associate Programme Management Officer (National Professional Officer),  one Associate Administrative Officer (National Professional Officer), and one Data Analysis Officer (National Professional Officer). Given the continuity of the UNSMIL mine action programme in 2026, it is proposed that the eight temporary positions be continued to advance the UNSMIL mine action objectives in the most effective, cost-efficient and transparent manner.

The decrease in requirements for 2026 compared with the approved resources for 2025 is attributable mainly to: (a) reduced requirements for civilian personnel, owing to the application of a 100 per cent vacancy rate to 35 posts vacant for more than 3 years (15 international, one National Professional Officer and 19 Local level) as described in paragraph ‎181 above, offset by the application of lower vacancy rates for all categories of personnel, and the application of lower continuing vacancy rates for the eight positions (3 P-4, 1 P-3 and 3 National Professional Officer) that were approved for establishment in 2025 and budgeted with a vacancy rate of 50 per cent; (b) reduced requirements for air operations in line with historical flight hour utilization rates; and (c) reduced requirements under military contingents for the United Nations Guard Unit personnel, owing to the non-requirement for rations due to anticipated stock availability from prior period procurement, as well as the removal of a provision for death and disability compensation following a review of historical expenditure pattern. The decrease is offset in part by increased requirements under: (a) facilities and infrastructure, due to additional requirements for the construction of a new road and parking area, fuel station, construction of the infrastructure networks and other security enhancements in connection with Phase 2 of the planned security enhancements works in the Mission’s compound; and (b) new requirements for the quick-impact projects mentioned in paragraph ‎174 above.
Extrabudgetary resources

In 2025, extrabudgetary resources in the amount of $241,544 are projected to be utilized to support activities focused on facilitating an inclusive intra Libyan political process an economic track as well as capacity-building on human rights.

In 2026, extrabudgetary resources in the amount of $157,200 are projected to be used to assist in the implementation of an inclusive multi-track intra-Libyan political dialogue process facilitated by UNSMIL, to unify institutions and take the country to elections.
The decrease in the estimated extrabudgetary resources to be utilized in 2026 compared with 2025 is due mainly to the duration of funding in support of the capacity-building on human rights.

In 2025, UNSMIL expects to receive $611,905 from United Nations agencies, funds, programmes, and other entities, in exchange for services provided including shared premises and the provision of security services across Libya. These funds will support one Local level post, medical services and the costs associated with maintaining United Nations compounds, including security services, rent, utilities, and maintenance services.

For 2026, UNSMIL expects to receive $611,905 from UN agencies, funds, and other programmes through the cost recovery arrangements. The estimate covers a wide range of services provided by the Mission, comprising air transportation, ground transportation, freight services, medical services, security and security-related training services, communications and information technology services, administrative support, accommodation and office space, personal protective equipment and maintenance of vehicles, facilities.

text: 8.	United Nations Verification Mission in Colombia

children.text: A.	Proposed programme plan for 2026 and programme performance in 2024
Overall orientation
Mandates and background

The United Nations Verification Mission in Colombia is mandated to verify five key aspects of the Final Agreement for Ending the Conflict and Building a Stable and Lasting Peace (hereinafter “the Final Agreement”), adopted in 2016 by the Government of Colombia and the former Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia – People’s Army (FARC-EP), comprising: (a) the reintegration of FARC-EP members into political, economic and social life (sect. 3.2 of the Agreement); (b) the implementation of personal and collective security and protection measures for ex-combatants, and comprehensive security and protection programmes for the communities and organizations in the territories (sect. 3.4 of the Agreement), since 2021; (c) compliance with and implementation of the restorative sentences issued by the Special Jurisdiction for Peace (sect. 5.1.2 of the Agreement); since 2023 (d) the verification of the comprehensive rural reform (sect. 1 of the Agreement); and; (e) the implementation of the ethnic chapter (sect. 6.2 of the Agreement).

Moreover, the Security Council, in its resolution 2694 (2023), expanded the Mission’s mandate to monitor and verify and the implementation of the Bilateral, National and Temporary Ceasefire Agreement between the Government of Colombia and the Ejército de Liberación Nacional (ELN).

The Mission’s mandate is defined in Security Council resolutions 2366 (2017), 2574 (2021), 2673 (2023) and 2694 (2023). By its resolution 2754 (2024), the Council renewed the mandate until 31 October 2025.
Programme of work
Objective

The objective, to which the Mission contributes, is to advance the effective implementation of the provisions of the Final Agreement concerning reintegration, security guarantees, restorative sentences, comprehensive rural reform and the ethnic chapter, and to advance the Ceasefire Agreement.
Strategy and external factors for 2026
To contribute to the objective, the Mission will:

Apply a proactive and inclusive approach to verification, which includes advocacy, good offices, and close engagement with the parties to the Final Agreement, and relevant institutions and authorities at the international, national, regional and local levels as well as communities, women and ethnic peoples;

Conduct independent verification of the implementation of the Final Agreement, and participate, jointly with the parties, in key forums and institutions created for the implementation of the Final Agreement;

Promote constructive dialogue and trust-building between the Government and the Comunes party to address pending issues relating to peace implementation and maintain constant coordination and dialogue with key interlocutors, including actors across the political spectrum, civil society, ethnic organizations, the private sector and the international community, to foster support for the implementation of the Final Agreement;

In keeping with commitments of the Pact for the Future, particularly Action 18, provide good offices to support the implementation of the Final Agreement, monitor conflict dynamics at local levels between armed groups, support the SRSG’s role in political peace dialogues, and help build and sustain peace in Colombia.
The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:

Increased trust between the parties to the Final Agreement; sustainability of the reintegration process, as well as opportunities for political participation with a specific focus on security guarantees for former combatants, social leaders and communities; progress in the implementation of key components of the comprehensive rural reform, including increased Government capacity to prevent and address land-related conflict and progress in the implementation of development plans with a territorial focus in prioritized areas, with the active participation of local communities;

Enhanced State capacity, presence and responsiveness to better prevent and investigate attacks against former combatants, social leaders and communities, as well as increased trust and understanding between the parties through tripartite coordination mechanisms, while taking into consideration the specific needs of women, children, former combatants of ethnic origin and other communities at risk;

Enhanced trust in the transitional justice system; the Government provides the conditions necessary for the Special Jurisdiction for Peace to ensure compliance with and implementation of its restorative sentences and to contribute to the realization of victims’ rights to truth, justice, reparation and non-repetition and their full inclusion in the restorative system;

Strengthened implementation of the ethnic provisions of the Final Agreement; enhanced coordination between government institutions, ethnic authorities and their organizations, including women-led organizations, and increased engagement of the international community, including the United Nations system; and
Increased trust in the peace dialogue efforts, thus contributing to a reduction in violence and improvements in the humanitarian situation in conflict-affected regions.

Regarding cooperation with other entities, the Mission engages extensively with international, national and local actors in support of its mandate. At the international level, the Mission’s close engagement with the diplomatic community and regional organisations helps to identify areas of mutual interest and support for peace consolidation. At the national and local levels, the Mission strengthens ties with political, civil society and private sector actors, including community, religious, youth, women, and ethnic leaders and persons with disabilities’ organisations, and transitional justice institutions. The Mission continues to bolster its relationships with departmental and local authorities, particularly as they gain more responsibilities regarding the reintegration process, ensuring security guarantees for communities and supporting society’s participation in the peace process.

Regarding inter-agency coordination, the Mission continues to work closely with the United Nations country team and Resident Coordinator. Through the revised United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework, the Mission and the country team developed five priorities establishing linkages between sustainable peace and the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, promoting coherence across the peace and security and the development pillars.
Regarding external factors, the plan for 2026 is based on the following planning assumptions:

Continued international support for the close engagement of the Mission and the United Nations system in the peace process. National and local authorities and relevant parties remain committed to collaborating with the Mission;
The Government and legislature will remain focused on the implementation of the Final Agreement;

National and local authorities remain engaged in increasing State presence; Authorities, State entities, and mechanisms tasked with preventing, addressing and investigating security incidents will remain committed to the prioritized populations in the Peace Agreement in conflict-affected areas;
Continued progress in judicial processes before the Special Jurisdiction for Peace, resulting in the issuance and implementation of restorative sentences; and
The Government and ELN resume the peace efforts with a view to reducing violence.

The Mission integrates a gender perspective into its activities, deliverables and results and ensures the adequate implementation of its gender parity directives and strategy. The Mission ensures that the specific needs of former FARC-EP women are fully incorporated into programme design, implementation and monitoring, particularly the security guarantees of women leaders and ex-combatants, referrals to assistance provided by Colombian authorities for victims and survivors of conflict, including from sexual and gender-based violence. The Mission fosters a gender perspective and intersectional analysis in the verification of restorative sentences, in particular concerning case 11 and others relating to sexual and gender-based violence, as well as in rural reform and the ethnic chapter, with a specific focus on the needs of peasant and ethnic women. The Mission, in line with the Pact for the Future, Action 19, provides support to the National Action Plan on Security Council resolution 1325 (2000) adopted in 2024, which is expected to strengthen the implementation of the gender provisions of the Final Agreement and reinforce the full, equal and meaningful participation of women in peacemaking.
Programme performance in 2024
Enhanced conditions for the Implementation of the Final Peace Agreement

In October 2024, the Government adopted a Rapid Response Plan to accelerate the implementation of the Final Agreement, which includes the establishment of pacts between national and local authorities to accelerate the implementation of the Development Programmes with a Territorial Focus (PDET) and to enhance their transformative potential in conflict-affected regions; as well as actions related to the comprehensive rural reform and security guarantees, among others. The Mission, through the good offices of the Special Representative of the Secretary-General and the technical teams, accompanied the Government in the formulation of the plan, including identifying key territorial priorities to be included in the pacts between national and local authorities. The Plan underlined the execution of development and infrastructure projects in key regions for the Peace Agreement, thus mobilising resources and engaging relevant local actors to accelerate the implementation of the Final Agreement.
Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 43)
Table 43
Performance measure –

table_content.text:

children.text: Planned results for 2026
Result 1: progress in the effective implementation of comprehensive rural reform and ethnic chapters – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

In 2024, the Mission focused on institutional coordination and consensus-building for the implementation of the rural reform and ethnic chapter, leading to agreements to boost the implementation of ethnic chapter in the Department of Chocó, timely land distribution and the delivery of productive assets to relevant actors.

In 2026, the Mission will take stock of the Government's goals and promote continuity of strategies and policies related to the implementation of the comprehensive rural reform and ethnic chapter. Efforts will aim at advancing the comprehensive rural reform at the local and departmental levels and fulfilling the commitments outlined in the ethnic chapter.
Progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see table 44).

children.text: Result 2: strengthened security conditions for communities in conflict-affected areas through advances in the implementation of the Final Agreement and effective implementation of the Ceasefire Agreement between the Government and the Ejército de Liberación Nacional – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

In 2024, the Mission was instrumental to advancing security and protection measures for former combatants and communities, including the adoption of the public policy for dismantling illegal armed groups and criminal organizations and strengthening the framework of the strategic security and protection plan. The Mission, through the Monitoring and Verification Mechanism of the Ceasefire Agreement, contributed to violence reduction, while closely monitoring local conflict dynamics. Although the parties did not renew the Ceasefire Agreement, they met twice in efforts to overcome obstacles to a possible resumption of the ceasefire.

In 2026, the Mission will continue to advance prevention and protection policies, analyse conflict dynamics. The Special Representative of the Secretary-General will continue his good offices role in peace dialogues.
Progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see table 45).
Table 45 – Performance measure

table_content.text:
Prevented confrontations between the parties and supported the de-escalation of violence in the regions: four fatalities among ELN members and security forces recorded during the ceasefire (Aug. 2023 – Aug. 2024)
Enhanced policies and plans on security guarantees for former combatants and affected communities:  approval of the public policy on dismantling of criminal organizations and armed groups; implementation of the emergency evacuation and extraction protocol and strengthening of the Special Investigations Unit.

Progress in the implementation of the Ceasefire Agreement between the Government and ELN
Ceasefire agreements and protocols are enhanced, including through technical support provided by the Mission within its participation in the Monitoring and Verification Mechanism
Reduction in violent clashes between public forces and illegal armed groups
Improved security conditions for communities in conflict-affected areas as a result of the ceasefire

Implementation of the public policy on dismantling of criminal organizations and armed groups in two pilot areas, acceleration of its implementation in the other 11 prioritized areas
Implemented prevention and protection mechanisms and policies 
Reduced violence, through increased access to programmes for former combatants, leaders and organizations in rural areas 
Reduced violence between armed groups and public forces; improved security in conflict-affected areas.
Enhanced trust between the parties to the peace dialogues.

children.text: Result 3: Effective implementation of restorative sentences for the restoration of victims’ rights and legal certainty for those under Special Jurisdiction for Peace – Proposed programme plan for 2026

In 2025, the Mission anticipates the issuance of the first restorative sentences by the Peace Tribunal of the Special Jurisdiction for Peace cases 1 and 3, the first since the signing of the Final Agreement. The Mission has engaged with relevant entities, fine-tuning methodology and strengthening the monitoring and verification mechanism and information-sharing mechanisms. The Mission engaged with institutions responsible for ensuring that conditions for the implementation of the restorative sentences are fulfilled.
Lessons learned and planned changes

Despite advances, there has been limited progress towards the issuance of restorative sentences, with four cases in trial phase. To help remedy the situation, the Mission will increase its advocacy and good offices with relevant entities, disseminating information on the transitional justice system to build trust between the parties and communities, including through the Monitoring and Verification Mechanism of restorative sentences established with the Special Jurisdiction for Peace.
Progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see table 46)
Table 46 – Performance measure

table_content.text:
The Monitoring and Verification Mechanism of restorative sentences with the Special Jurisdiction for Peace is fully operational and provides relevant information for verification purposes
The Mission verifies that the State institutions provide conditions for the effective implementation of the restorative sentences
Compliance with the restorative sentences by individuals subject to the Special Jurisdiction for Peace is verified
