children.text: B.	Proposed post and non-post resource requirements for 2026
Resource requirements (regular budget) – Table 48 – Financial resources
(Thousands of United States dollars)
Table 49 – Human resources
a	Other level, unless otherwise stated.

The proposed resource requirements for 2026 for the Mission amount to $86,953,100 (net of staff assessment) and would provide for the deployment of 188 military observers ($6,480,800), salaries and common staff costs ($47,383,800) for 181 international posts (1 Under-Secretary-General, 1 Assistant Secretary-General, 6 D-1, 26 P-5, 38 P-4, 58 P-3, 2 P-2 and 49 Field Service), 218 national posts (113 National Professional Officer, 1 General Service and 104 Local level) and 183 United Nations Volunteers (153 international and 30 national), and operational costs ($33,088,500), comprising the costs for consultants and consulting services ($458,800), official travel ($2,106,200), facilities and infrastructure ($8,144,900), ground transportation ($2,274,100), air operations ($12,116,300), marine operations ($462,000), communications and information technology ($5,084,400), medical ($427,800) and other supplies, services and equipment ($2,014,000).
A vacancy rate of 7.5 per cent has been applied to military observers based on the actual average vacancy rate during 2024.

A vacancy rate of 18.8 per cent has been applied to the estimates for international staff and 30.1 per cent for National Professional Officers based on the actual vacancy rate in March 2025; 28.1 per cent for the Local level categories staff based on the actual average vacancy rate in 2024. Vacancy rates of 5.0 per cent and 7.0 per cent have been applied to international and national United Nations Volunteers, respectively, based on the actual vacancy rates in March 2025. A vacancy rate of 50 per cent has been applied to the estimates for the posts proposed for reassignment.

To ensure effective mandate delivery, a number of changes to the organizational and staffing structure are proposed for 2026, including the redeployment of three posts to increase conflict analysis capacities in key Offices as the fragmentation of armed groups, the increasingly localized conflicts and threats to former combatants that could impact the implementation of the Final Agreement; as well the reassignment of two posts, as detailed below:
Office of the Special Representative of the Secretary-General

Redeployment of one post of Assistant Public Information Officer (National Professional Officer), from the Information Management Unit under the Office of the Deputy Special Representative of the Secretary-General, to the Strategic Communications and Public Information Unit within the Office of the Special Representative of the Secretary-General, to assist in promoting public awareness on the Mission mandate and the peace process. Efforts are needed to enhance strategic communication and reach a larger audience with consistent and balanced information, as well as raise awareness about the Peace Agreement, in particular in anticipation of the first restorative sentences by the Special Jurisdiction for Peace Tribunal, expected in 2026. The incumbent will assist in producing critical graphic and communication materials nationwide and awareness-raising campaigns boosting trust in the transitional justice system.
Office of the Verification of Security Guarantees

Redeployment of one long-vacant post of Liaison Officer (National Professional Officer) from the Regional Office of Florencia to the Office of the Verification of Security Guarantees within the same Office of the Deputy Special Representative of the Secretary-General in Bogota. The Liaison Officer will analyse evolving conditions nationwide, including threats, actors and dynamics, for expanded conflict analysis and assessment of potential impact to former combatants and victims of the conflict for preventative recommendations, preparedness, advocacy, and engagement at the national level.
Office of the Chief of Staff

Redeployment of one long vacant post of Liaison Officer (National Professional Officer) from the Regional Office of Villavicencio to the Office of the Chief of Staff in Bogota to improve information gathering situational awareness and analysis for strategic recommendations to the SRSG and Mission leadership.
Transport Unit

Reassignment of one vacant post of Field Security Assistant (Local level) from the Security Section’s presence in Arauca to the Transport Unit as a Driver (Local level) to provide dedicated capacity to the Deputy Special Representative of the Secretary-General;
Financial Resourcing, Performance and Risk Management Unit

Reassignment of one post of Field Security Assistant (Local level) from the Regional Security Section’s presence in Ocaña to the Financial Resourcing, Performance and Risk Management Unit in Bogota as a Finance and Budget Assistant (Local level) to contribute to better informed decision-making. This will ensure robust financial management and operational efficiency especially while the Mission is experiencing liquidity constraints and needs to implement additional management measures.

The increase in requirements for 2026 compared with the appropriation for 2025 is attributable mainly to: (a) increased requirements for military observers due to the increase in the mission subsistence allowance rates (higher actual daily rate of the "after 30 days" mission subsistence allowances of $94 effective 1 January 2025 compared with the rate of $63 applied in the approved budget for 2025) as well as application of a lower vacancy rate of 7.5 per cent compared to 10.1 per cent in 2025 budget; (b) additional requirements for international United Nations Volunteers due to increased monthly living allowance; (c) increased requirements for air operations due to a change in contractual arrangements, which increased guaranteed fleet costs, and to additional flight hours for fixed-wing and rotary-wing aircraft and related requirements for aviation fuel necessary to support mandate implementation in the locations outside Bogota and ensure connectivity between locations; and (d) increased requirements for marine operations to support additional riverine activities to cover an enlarged mission area especially the locations that are not accessible by ground nor air transportation. The increased requirements are offset in part by: (a) reduced requirements for international staff owing to lower estimated common staff costs (estimated common staff costs as a percentage of salary costs of 51.7 per cent compared to 56.8 per cent in the 2025 budget); (b) reduced requirements for national staff owing to the application of higher vacancy rates for National Professional Officers and Local level staff; (c) reduced requirements for consultants owing to the higher reliance on in-house expertise; (d) reduced requirements under facilities and infrastructure owing to lower estimated costs for the rental of premises and non-acquisition of furniture; (e) lower estimated costs for rental of vehicles owing to efficiencies gained through the full transfer of rental of vehicles to the United Nations fleet modality; (f) fewer acquisition of communication and information technology equipment; (g) lower requirements for medical services; (h) lower requirements for freight due to fewer acquisition; and (i) lower requirements under other services, owing to a planned reduction in meeting facilitation, as a cost avoidance measure.

text: 9.	United Nations Mission to Support the Hudaydah Agreement

children.text: A.	Proposed programme plan for 2026 and programme performance in 2024
Overall orientation
Mandates and background

The United Nations Mission to support the Hudaydah Agreement is responsible for supporting the parties to the Stockholm Agreement (S/2018/1134, annex) in implementing the provisions of the Agreement on the City of Hudaydah and the Ports of Hudaydah, Salif and Ra’s Isa (Hudaydah Agreement), and their commitments in accordance with the Hudaydah Agreement. The mandate derives from Security Council resolution 2452 (2019) and was extended in subsequent resolutions, most recently in resolution 2742 (2024).

The mandate of the Mission is to: (a) lead, and support the functioning of the Redeployment Coordination Committee, assisted by a secretariat staffed with United Nations personnel, to oversee the Governorate-wide ceasefire, the redeployment of forces and mine action operations; (b) monitor the compliance of the parties with the ceasefire in Hudaydah Governorate and the mutual redeployment of forces from the city of Hudaydah and the ports of Hudaydah, Salif and Ra’s Isa; (c) work with the parties so that local security forces assure the security of the city of Hudaydah and the ports of Hudaydah, Salif and Ra’s Isa in accordance with Yemeni law; and (d) facilitate and coordinate United Nations support to assist the parties to fully implement the Hudaydah Agreement.
Programme of work – Objective

The objective, to which the Mission contributes, is to support the parties in the implementation of the Hudaydah Agreement on the City of Hudaydah and the Ports of Hudaydah, Salif and Ra’s Isa, and their commitments in accordance with the Agreement.
Strategy and external factors for 2026
To contribute to the objective, the Mission will:

Lead and support the sustained operation of the Redeployment Coordination Committee as the key oversight body of the Hudaydah Agreement, while strengthening and realigning the joint structures previously agreed as part of the framework of the Committee to address shifted realities and conflict-affected areas in the evolved environment, including de-escalation, dialogue and liaison mechanisms in a joint format;

Maintain increased monitoring capacity within the authorized ceiling to expand and strengthen monitoring of the ports with regular patrols to all port installations, with a view to monitoring the redeployment of all military forces from such locations, and the removal of military manifestations, in accordance with the mandate. On-the-ground patrolling will also be expanded in the territories held by the parties on either side of the front lines, including conflict-affected areas;

Adapt to the evolving environment across Hudaydah Governorate to ensure it is best positioned to advance its mandate, which will include establishing and operating a presence in Al-Khawkhah district under the Government of Yemen south of the current front lines, in conjunction with the operation of its base in Hudaydah city, to ensure equitable representation across the territories of both parties;

Provide technical support, incident data management and advocacy to advance mine action efforts in Hudaydah Governorate, in close coordination with the Resident and Humanitarian Coordinator for Yemen and other partners and in accordance with the priorities identified by both sides with a focus on locations posing a high risk to civilians;

Advance assessment and coordination to implement community-focused projects in key locations on either side of the front lines, with a focus on vulnerable groups, including conflict-affected groups, women, youth, and children, and in coordination with and fully complementary to wider development action that supports the local population, de-escalates tensions between communities, strengthens social cohesion and enhances stability; and

Further strengthen monitoring processes and procedures through enhanced real-time situational awareness, data integration and robust watchkeeping, aligning with United Nations-wide priorities such as UN 2.0 and the Pact for the Future, while reinforcing crisis management and contingency planning.
The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
Enhanced trust, confidence and dialogue between the parties to strengthen the implementation of the Hudaydah Agreement as a key contribution to the broader peace process;
Equal and sustained access on both sides of the frontline in the relevant territories of the parties in Hudaydah Governorate;
Strengthened ceasefire implementation across the Governorate and improved security of the local population, including a reduction in casualties resulting from ceasefire violations;

Maintenance of the security of Hudaydah city and its ports, and assurance that military forces are redeployed from such locations, remaining military manifestations are removed and security responsibilities are assumed by local security forces in accordance with Yemeni law in these locations;
Reduced violence in Hudaydah Governorate due to the de-escalation of tensions between the parties, enhanced stability and strengthened measures to protect the local population;

Advancement of mine action interventions in Hudaydah city, its ports and other priority locations, reducing the risk of civilian casualties caused by mines and explosive remnants of war, including the coordination of mine action efforts, provision of technical advice to stakeholders, risk awareness sessions, and advocacy;

Enhanced process to ensure implementation of the Hudaydah Agreement on the basis of inclusive and strengthened women’s and youth's meaningful participation in efforts towards bringing and sustaining peace.

With regard to cooperation with other entities, the Mission liaises with the parties to ensure the safety and security of mission personnel and premises, and the unhindered movement of mission personnel and equipment, provisions and essential supplies into and within Yemen. The Mission engages, where possible, with local stakeholders, partners and other bodies within Hudaydah Governorate to ensure a unified approach in supporting the Hudaydah Agreement and its implementation and identifying opportunities to enhance stability and confidence in this process while increasing awareness of its mandate. The Mission maintains its engagements with regional actors that can have a positive influence on progress towards mandate implementation.

Regarding inter-agency coordination, the Mission coordinates closely with the Office of the Special Envoy of the Secretary-General for Yemen. The two entities share information and analysis, coordinate movements, cooperate on briefings to the Security Council and align messaging, while sharing a mission support structure and premises in common locations to ensure the prudent use of resources. Operationally, UNMHA continues its partnership with the United Nations country team on matters related to health facilities, security, premises, CASEVAC by air using United Nations Humanitarian Air Service (UNHAS) and UNMHA flights whenever required. The Mission maintains close working relationships with the Resident and Humanitarian Coordinator and members of the United Nations country team, in particular the World Food Programme, United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund, United Nations Development Programme and the Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs, as well as other development and humanitarian actors operating in Hudaydah Governorate as part of its comprehensive approach to mandate implementation. The Mission also consults and coordinates, as necessary, with the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights and UN Women to this end.
Regarding external factors, the overall plan for 2026 is based on the following planning assumptions:
There is sufficient political will and engagement from domestic, regional and international stakeholders to enable the implementation of the Hudaydah Agreement;
Efforts to attain a nationwide durable ceasefire, led by the Office of the Special Envoy of the Secretary-General for Yemen will progress;
Major combat operations between the parties will not recommence in Hudaydah Governorate, while the impact of the situation in the region will not exacerbate local conditions;
A political environment exists that facilitates the work of the Redeployment Coordination Committee and its subsidiary joint mechanisms;

The parties resume their full participation in the activities of the Redeployment Coordination Committee and commit themselves to a revived dialogue process and participation in subsidiary joint mechanisms to monitor the ceasefire and foster de-escalation, confidence-building, and collaborative demining efforts;

The Government of Yemen continues to support the establishment of a Mission presence in the south of the governorate to ensure the Mission’s equitable access to both parties and its unimpeded functioning;

A suitably safe, secure and permissive operating environment exists, and sufficient confidence is established between the parties and other partners to generate sustained support for and participation in the activities of the Mission;

The parties facilitate the Mission’s full access and freedom of movement to all areas required for the effective observation and monitoring of the ports of Hudaydah, Ra’s Isa and Salif to enable daily access to all port installations and to conflict-affected areas across the governorate; and

The parties provide the access and cooperation required to advance mine action interventions in Hudaydah city, the ports, and areas of priority in other districts to enhance the protection of the local population in the Governorate’s shifted context.

UNMHA integrates gender perspectives and Women, Peace, and Security and Youth, Peace, and Security agenda into its operations and activities in line with the Department of Peacebuilding and Political Affairs’ Policy on Women, Peace, and Security. The Mission continues to advance the role of women and youth in carrying out its mandate and advocate for a gender-inclusive approach to the implementation of the Hudaydah Agreement. It will expand its work in empowering women leaders to meaningfully contribute to peacebuilding in Hudaydah Governorate, while also fostering a grassroots approach to women’s involvement in community-level initiatives in conflict-affected districts. Gender considerations will be mainstreamed across the Mission’s conflict and political analysis, and through the delivery and monitoring of its quick-impact projects.

In line with the United Nations Disability Inclusion Strategy and in furtherance of its Mission-specific Disability Inclusion Strategy, the Mission will continue to promote an inclusive process to implementing the Hudaydah Agreement; amplify the stories of persons with disabilities in Hudaydah, particularly the victims of mine and explosive remnants of war; mainstream disability inclusion into quick impact project design and implementation; build partnerships with local organizations for persons with disabilities, disability centres, and international NGOs; and build upon the progress made in improving physical access to Mission facilities for persons with disabilities.
Programme performance in 2024
Enhanced engagement with the parties resulted in strengthened implementation of key elements of the mandate and the Hudaydah Agreement

In 2024, local, national and regional developments, including attacks in and around the Red Sea by the Houthis (who call themselves Ansar Allah) since November 2023 and corresponding airstrikes on multiple targets in Hudaydah Governorate and beyond since January 2024, have demonstrated that local dynamics in Hudaydah and parties’ attitudes towards the Hudaydah Agreement are significantly affected by regional dynamics. These developments also continue to impact the Mission’ ability to deliver its mandate and affect the safety and security of its personnel.

Despite the extremely challenging political and security situation, in its efforts to reinvigorate parties’ commitments to the Hudaydah Agreement and the implementation of its mandate, the Mission reinforced its engagement with the parties focusing on achieving systematic patrolling to the Ports of Hudaydah, Ra’s Isa and Salif and expanding areas for collaboration in the south of the governorate with the Government of Yemen, through key leadership engagement and separate but regular meetings with the members of the Redeployment Coordination Committee from both sides and by leveraging quick impact projects. These efforts resulted in enhanced engagement of the parties in strengthened implementation of key elements of the mandate and the Hudaydah Agreement, including a doubling of the frequency of patrols to the Hudaydah Port since March 2024, a 22 per cent increase in overall patrolling compared to 2023 including into other areas in the southern districts of the governorate, and several important breakthroughs between the Mission and the Government of Yemen, particularly on the expansion of Mission's presence in the southern districts of Hudaydah Governorate.
Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 50).
Table 50 – Performance measure –

table_content.text: Improved situational awareness and analytical products supported partner planning and programming in Hudaydah Governorate
Increased joint monitoring visits with United Nations country team members enhanced coordination in conflict-affected districts

Strengthened support to the implementation of the Hudaydah Agreement by the parties, demonstrated through increased patrolling and increased collaboration between the Mission and Government of Yemen in support of the mandate

children.text: Planned results for 2026

Result 1: establishment of a physical mission presence in Government of Yemen-controlled territory in Hudaydah Governorate to build confidence of the parties towards the Hudaydah Agreement – Proposed programme plan for 2026

In 2024, the Mission crossed an important milestone in the establishment of a presence in Government of Yemen-controlled territory by securing Governmental approval, identifying the site in the Al-Khawkhah district and signing a lease and contract for construction works at the site in December 2024. The construction of the site will commence in 2025. Once an initial UNMHA presence is established and operational, UNMHA expects to increase the number of monitoring patrols to the frontline and enhanced engagement with the local authorities and communities within the mandate area. Further transition to full operating capability is planned to take place in 2026, which will provide additional opportunities for cooperation with local partners in implementing the Hudaydah Agreement and further strengthen trust towards the Mission.
Expected progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 51).
Table 51 – Performance measure

table_content.text: Establishment of the Mokha’ hub for operations in southern Hudaydah Governorate
Regular monitoring visits to southern Hudaydah Governorate
Site identified, and lease and construction contracts signed
UNMHA installation established in Al-Khawkhah district

Increased confidence and engagement of the parties and local political, military leaders and community towards the Hudaydah Agreement and the Mission following the deployment of core team to Al-Khawkhah

children.text: Result 2:re-established dialogue between the parties at the technical level promotes confidence building and de-escalation – Proposed programme plan for 2026

Engaging the parties in regular technical and operational-level discussions is crucial for de-escalating hostilities, building confidence, fostering trust, and identifying collaborative opportunities between the parties to mitigate the impact of conflict on civilians in frontline areas of Hudaydah. The engagement will also help prepare the ground for the re-establishment of a joint Redeployment Coordination Committee. The Mission has routinely approached the parties to re-establish a technical-level forum and has identified a range of issues that can be explored as confidence building measures. These efforts have been met with initial positivity by the parties, which will be leveraged to provide space and opportunities for further dialogue in 2025 and 2026.
Lessons learned and planned change

The lesson for the Mission was that sustained engagement and the identification of varied options for trust-building initiatives could resonate with the parties as the situation on the ground developed, providing windows of opportunity which the Mission must respond to in an agile manner. In applying the lesson, UNMHA will pursue an iterative approach that can bring the parties together on issues of shared concern.
Expected progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 52)
Table 52 – Performance measure

table_content.text: The parties demonstrate willingness to engage on technical-level discussions on confidence-building measures
Confidence between the parties develops and topics for discussion and a suitable location for joint meetings are agreed upon
Increased levels of trust lead to the parties agreeing to a regular meeting schedule and convening joint meetings

children.text: Evaluation activities

An internal evaluation was completed in 2024 on UNMHA’s logistical and operational support to the Floating Storage and Offloading Vessel Safer (FSO Safer) salvage operation. Based on the findings, conclusions and lessons learned explored in the final evaluation report, the Mission took actions in areas related to operational improvements in crisis preparedness, contingency planning, situational awareness and analysis. These findings also highlighted expanded avenues for cooperation with the United Nations country team that would allow UNMHA to build upon its role as a technical resource for the United Nations family in Hudaydah as appropriate. The application of the findings from the evaluation has supported the Mission’s broader mandate implementation through identifying operational and logistical efficiencies in pursuit of the Mission’s objectives.

The scope for an internal evaluation to be carried out in 2026 is yet to be determined, but its purpose may include informing operational and strategic planning for the Mission’s expanding presence and activities in the south of Hudaydah Governorate.
B.	Proposed post and non-post resource requirements for 2026
Resource requirements (regular budget) – Table 54 – Financial resources
(Thousands of United States dollars)
Table 55 – Human resources
a	Includes one P-4 and one P-3 general temporary assistance position.

The proposed resource requirements for 2026 for the Mission amount to $30,040,500 (net of staff assessment) and would provide for the deployment of 75 United Nations monitors ($651,700), salaries and common staff costs ($14,568,300) for 71 international staff posts (1 Assistant Secretary-General, 1 D-2, 1 D-1, 6 P-5, 13 P-4, 18 P-3 and 31 Field Service), 92 national staff posts (11 National Professional Officer and 81 Local level) and 5 government-provided personnel, and operational costs ($14,820,500), comprising the costs for official travel ($508,800), facilities and infrastructure ($5,778,900), ground transportation ($578,200), air operations ($4,346,900), communications and information technology ($1,467,400), medical ($1,107,600), other supplies, services and equipment ($732,700) and quick-impact projects ($300,000).

A vacancy rate of 85.3 per cent has been applied to the estimates for United Nations monitors based on the actual average vacancy rates in 2024. A vacancy rate of 27.5 per cent for international staff posts has been applied based on the actual average vacancy rate in 2024. Vacancy rates of 50.0 per cent for National Professional Officers and 20.6 per cent for Local level posts have been applied based on the actual vacancy rates in March 2025. A vacancy rate of 100.0 per cent has been applied to the estimates for government-provided personnel in view of the lack of incumbency. A vacancy rate of 50.0 per cent has been applied for the posts proposed for establishment and reassignment.
With a view to ensuring the effective delivery of its mandate, the following staffing changes are proposed for 2026, as detailed below:
Office of the Chief of Staff

Reassignment of one post of Coordination Officer (P-3) in the Office of the Chief of Mission Support in Djibouti to Data Specialist (P-3) in the Office of the Chief of Staff in Hudaydah to support the Mission in all aspects of its mandate delivery by providing data-related advice, and in further enhancing a forward-thinking and data-driven Mission while strengthening its information security and data management processes. Due to the sensitive nature of the data to be handled and the level of expertise required in data system design, management and analysis, the post is proposed to be established at the P-3 level.
Political Affairs Section

Redeployment of one post of Political Affairs Officer (P-4) from Sana’a to Al-Khawkhah to support political efforts that can bring further stability in the Hudaydah Governorate. Following an internal review of the Mission’s strategic direction and priorities in July 2024, the Mission identified the imperative for a revised political engagement plan, with particular focus on the south of Hudaydah Governorate and those areas that are under the control of the Government of Yemen. Having a dedicated political affairs capacity based in Al-Khawkhah is critical to realising this aim and further strengthening political outreach that is responsive to local dynamics.

Redeployment of one post of Associate Political Affairs Officer (National Professional Officer) from Sana’a to Hudaydah to support political efforts to further stability in the Hudaydah Governorate. The Mission currently does not have a dedicated political affairs capacity at the national level in Hudaydah city, where the Mission headquarters are located. A national Political Affairs Officer in Hudaydah will be integral to the Mission’s efforts to strengthen its liaison with the authorities in Hudaydah in support of the implementation of the Hudaydah Agreement and with local actors in conflict-affected districts.
Office of the Chief of Mission Support

Abolishment of one post of Coordination Officer (National Professional Officer) in Riyadh in line with UNMHA efforts to enhance efficiency, optimize resource utilisation and leverage support from the existing capacities of the United Nations Resident Coordinator Office in Saudi Arabia for the liaison functions.
Operations and Resource Management Section

Establishment of one post of the Telecommunication Technician (Field Service) in Al-Khawkhah following the Mission’s planned expansion in the southern region of Hudaydah Governorate and to ensure uninterrupted information and communication technology support for UNMHA premises in Al-Khawkhah. The incumbent will oversee information and communication technology infrastructure and ensure a smooth communication channel between Al-Khawkhah and other UNMHA offices;

Abolishment of one post of Finance and Budget Officer (National Professional Officer) in the Finance and Budget Unit, in Hudaydah that was approved in 2023 and has been vacant for 2 years; and establishment of one post of Finance and Budget Assistant (Local level) in Sana’a to support the Finance and Budget Unit in preparation of resource estimates and budget implementation reports, analysis of detailed expenditure reports with other support and substantive sections, review of expenditure patterns, processing of budget transactions, client support and other tasks and data analysis that are currently performed by available staff within the Unit.

Establishment of one post of Procurement Assistant (Local level) post in Sana’a to manage the volume of procurement tasks effectively in the Procurement Unit, which supports both the Office of the Special Envoy for Yemen and the Mission. The proposal to establish the new post in Sana’a is based on the overall number of transactions conducted by the Procurement Unit, which is 85% related to operations in Yemen.
Supply Chain and Service Delivery Section

Establishment of one post of Chief of Unit, Engineering and Facilities Management Unit (P-4) given the increased responsibilities of the post in planning, implementation, maintenance, operation and optimisation of facilities of both UNMHA and the Office of the Special Envoy. UNMHA plans to set up a new office in Al-Khawkhah, to enhance its operational and monitoring capabilities, while ensuring equitable representation and access on both sides of the conflict;

Abolishment of one post of Engineering Technician (Field Service) in Hudaydah as its original functions and terms of reference no longer cover the scope and complexity of responsibilities, which have increased since the Mission was established. In addition, the workload of the Engineering and Facilities Management Unit has further increased with the planned establishment of new facilities in the south of the Governorate. Therefore, it is proposed to abolish this Field Service post and establish the above-mentioned Chief of Engineering and Facilities Management Unit (P-4) to enhance the capacity;

Reclassification of post of Supply Officer (P-3), Hudaydah, to Chief of Unit (P-4), Central Warehousing and Supply in Hudaydah due to the increased responsibilities and workload of the post. To facilitate mandate implementation in the challenging operational environment, both missions maintain widely dispersed supply chains and life support routes across all field locations. To ensure uninterrupted services the incumbent is required to supervises supply officers of sub-units in five geographic areas;

Redeployment of one post of Supply Assistant (Local level) in the Central Warehousing and Supply Unit in Hudaydah to Aden to fill the gap in processing goods issuance for both Aden and Mokha offices, stock management, receipt and distribution of supplies, market research for urgent petty cash purchases in support of urgent requirements;

Redeployment of nine posts of Drivers (Local level) in the Transport Unit from Hudaydah, to Sana’a, Aden, and Al-Khawkhah to support regular escorted road convoys between Aden and Mokha, and movements between Sana’a and Hudaydah. In addition, to support UNMHA’s expansion to Al-Khawkhah where the incumbents will be responsible for facilitating movement for ceasefire monitoring teams, supporting mine action activities, and ensuring safe and efficient transport for community engagement and implementation of quick impact projects;

Reassignment of one post of Driver (Local level) in the Transport Unit from Hudaydah as Team Assistant in the Field Technology Unit in Amman, aimed at addressing critical staffing challenges currently faced by the Unit’s staff located in Amman. The Team Assistant will support essential tasks such as telephone billing, ICT asset management and tracking for new and outgoing staff;

Reassignment of one post of Driver (Local level) post in the Transport Unit from Hudaydah to Team Assistant in the Movement Control Unit in Aden to manage movement control including logistics, scheduling and coordination among multiple stakeholders southern Yemen such as liaison with customs, airport, seaport and other local authorities;

Reassignment of one post of Driver (Local level) in Transport Unit from Hudaydah, as Team Assistant in the Central Warehousing and Supply Unit in Amman, to support planning and coordination of life support consumables, write-offs, property disposal, and physical destruction of assets; and

Reassignment of two posts of Driver (Local level) in the Transport Unit from Hudaydah as Team Assistants (Local level) in the Aviation Unit in Sana’a and Aden respectively, to cover key air operations and aviation safety functions, which are currently performed by the Movement Control Unit. This gap is considered a significant risk for safe aviation operations and may expose the Mission to incidents/accidents.
Safety and Security Section

Reassignment of one post of Close Protection Officer (Field Service) in Hudaydah, as Administrative Assistant (Field Service) in the Safety and Security Section in Hudaydah, to manage the significant increase in administrative responsibilities. Currently, the administrative workload is being managed by security personnel whose primary role is security operations, leading to inefficient use of resources and delays in reporting and compliance, affecting timely responses required by United Nations policies and security protocols.
Backstopping support
Department of Operational Support,

Abolishment of one post of Associate Human Resource Officer (P-2) in the Division for Special Activities of the Department of Operational Support at the United Nations Headquarters in New York. The functions associated with the post are no longer required. The Mission’s existing capacity will perform human resources-related functions.
The Mission’s approved 2024 staffing table includes two general temporary assistance positions. It is proposed that these positions be continued in 2025:

Programme Management Officer (P-4) in the Office of the Deputy Head of Mission in Hudaydah, who would be required to continue to provide advice to the Head of Mission and senior leadership on landmine, explosive remnant of war, improvised explosive device and sea mine contamination, the associated risks to the United Nations and civilians, and preventive measure in place to ensure the safe mandate implementation by mission staff in Hudaydah Governorate;
Backstopping support – Department of Management Strategy, Policy and Compliance

Finance and Budget Officer (P-3) in the Field Operations Finance Division, which remains essential to perform backstopping support and continue to be essential in ensuring sufficient capacity at Headquarters for the planning and management of financial resources, the preparation of budgets and the provision of services to the legislative bodies during their review of the proposed budgets for special political missions.

The decrease in requirements for 2026 compared with the appropriation for 2025 is attributable mainly to: (a) decreased requirements for international staff due to the application of a higher vacancy rate of 27.5 per cent for the 2026 budget proposal compared to 25.4 per cent applied during 2025; (b) decreased requirements for National Professional Officers due to the application of a higher vacancy rate of 50.0 per cent for 2026 budget proposal compared to 25.8 per cent applied for 2025, as well as the proposed abolishment of two National Professional Officers posts; (c) decreased requirements for facilities and infrastructure due to reduced rental of premises including for the Mission’s locations in Sana’a and Hudaydah, reduced provision for construction, alteration, renovation and major maintenance as well as fewer acquisitions of spare parts and supplies and reduced requirements for generators fuel due to the discontinuation of the respective reserve; (d) decreased requirements for medical services due to lower estimates for the cost sharing of the medical clinic; (e) decreased requirements under other supplies, services and equipment due lower planned training fees and lower cost-share costs of support operations to UNMHA performed by the Kuwait Joint Support Office. The decreased costs were offset in part by: (a) application of a lower vacancy rate of 85.3 per cent for the United Nations monitors compared to 87.3 per cent in 2025; (b) establishment of the P-4 and P-3 posts lower vacancy rate for the United Nations monitors: (b) the establishment of additional international and Local level posts and revised salary scales in Amman; (c) additional acquisition of prefabricated facilities and accommodation, acquisition of generators and electric equipment, increased maintenance services for Al-Khawkah camp and increase in Security Services; (d) increased repairs and maintenance of ground fleet; (e) increased requirements for aviation fuel and increased air navigation charges.

text: 10.	United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti

children.text: A.	Proposed programme plan for 2026 and programme performance in 2024
Overall orientation
Mandates and background

The United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti (BINUH) is responsible for advising the Government of Haiti in promoting and strengthening political stability and good governance, including the rule of law; preserving and advancing a peaceful and stable environment, including through supporting an inclusive inter-Haitian national dialogue; and protecting and promoting human rights. The mandate derives from Security Council resolution 2476 (2019) and subsequent resolutions, including most recently resolution 2743 (2024), which extended the mandate of the Mission until 15 July 2025.

The Security Council, in its resolution 2743 (2024) called on BINUH to develop a strategy in consultation with the government of Haiti on how it will continue to support a Haitian-led and Haitian-owned political process, and to support the Haitian Government to develop and implement a strategic communications plan including to counter misinformation and disinformation regarding the work of state institutions and the political process. BINUH developed a political strategy addressing six areas of support: (a) facilitating an inclusive national dialogue; (b) supporting electoral and constitutional reforms; (c) enhancing public security; (d) strengthening the rule of law; (e) improving governance and institutional capacity; and (f) fostering United Nations system integration and regional partnerships. Implementation of the strategy and support on strategic communications is reported to the Security Council through the reports of the Secretary-General on a quarterly basis. In a series of public statements issued in January 2025, the transitional authorities reaffirmed their commitment to finalize the ongoing constitutional reform process and hold credible elections before the end of 2025.

BINUH redoubled its advisory efforts to mitigate possible disruptions to the political transition caused by the succession of three Prime Ministers between March and November 2024. These repeated changes in Haitian leadership coincided with a marked escalation in gang violence, which in November 2024 led to the closing of the international airport, the suspension of all commercial flights and a flight ban imposed by the United States Federal Aviation Administration over Haitian airspace. The United Nations Department of Safety and Security subsequently authorised the evacuation of Programme Criticality 2 (PC 2) personnel from the capital and the relocation of PC 1 and PC 2 personnel to the regions outside Port-au-Prince. The Designated Official, in consultation with the Security Management Team, decided to retain a ceiling of 133 UN personnel in the capital based on the assessed extraction capacity by air and road. Under this ceiling, BINUH maintains a skeleton team of 17 personnel headed by the Special Representative. Skeleton Team personnel are replaced by a pool of 51 international staff rotating on the rest and recuperation cycle every four weeks while the remaining international staff work remotely. Following this second evacuation in November 2024, the Secretary-General launched a strategic assessment and advised the Security Council on the full range of options for continued United Nations efforts in Haiti, which include increasing the robustness of BINUH to stay and deliver and establishing a UN logistic support office for the multinational security support Mission that would operate separately from BINUH.

The prevailing hostile operating environment is expected to persist, ruling out the return to Haiti of all the international personnel evacuated since November 2024. This situation triggered a review by the Secretariat of BINUH’s Mission Concept in April 2025 to update the planning assumptions and risks, notably the security considerations. The updated Mission Concept will prioritise BINUH’s mandated tasks and resources to be cost-effective in the prevailing operating environment. It will include recommendations to rationalize the mission’s structure, size and activities to ensure safe and effective mandate implementation. The Mission Concept review is expected to be largely completed in June 2025, prior to the Security Council’s consultations on the mission’s mandate extension in mid-July 2025. The Mission Concept will be finalized within three weeks after the issuance of the new mandate. The implications of the Mission Concept review and the new mandate, as approved by the Security Council, will be assessed and presented in the context of revised estimates.
Programme of work
Objective

The objective, to which the mission contributes, is to strengthen political stability and good governance, including accountability and the rule of law; restore a peaceful and stable environment; protect and promote human rights; and strengthen gender equality in Haiti.
Strategy and external factors for 2026
To contribute to the objective, the Mission will:

Update its political strategy in support of the national authorities to advance and facilitate a Haitian-led, Haitian-owned political process aimed at reaching an urgent agreement on a road map for constitutional reform and general elections;
Assist the Government in developing a communications plan to counter misinformation;

Reinforce the capacity of the Haitian National Police, including through training on human rights and crowd control, to respond to gang violence and sexual and gender-based violence and to maintain public order;
Improve the Directorate of Penitentiary Administration management and oversight of prison facilities to ensure proper treatment of inmates in accordance with international standards;
Develop an inclusive and comprehensive approach with all sectors of society to reduce community violence, in particular gang violence;
Address human rights abuses and violations with dedicated capacity to address sexual and gender-based violence and comply with international human rights obligations;

Work with UNODC and relevant United Nations agencies to support Haitian efforts in combating illicit financial flows, the trafficking in arms and enhancing the management and control of borders and ports;

Strengthen the criminal justice sector, including by promoting key reforms; support government efforts to improve internal oversight and accountability as they relate to corruption; address prolonged pre-trial detention; and ensure merit-based judicial appointments and the timely renewal of judicial mandates;

Include available information on cases of gang violence, criminal activities and human rights abuses in Haiti, collected in carrying out the BINUH mandate, as an annex to the report of the Secretary-General to the Security Council; and

Cooperate with the Security Council Committee established pursuant to resolution 2653 (2022) concerning Haiti and its Panel of Experts and use the good offices of the Secretary-General to encourage the Government to implement resolution 2653 (2022).
The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
An operational Provisional Electoral Council able to manage and handle multiple electoral functions across all 10 departments of the country;
Adoption of a revised constitution after the holding of a national referendum;
The holding of inclusive and credible general elections and the peaceful transfer of power at all levels; and
Installation of all elected officials and appointment of the government.

With regard to cooperation with other entities, BINUH collaborates with the Organization of American States, the Caribbean Community, and planners on the ground for the Multinational Security Support Mission in Haiti. The mission also engages closely with the diplomatic community, as appropriate.

With regard to inter-agency coordination and liaison, BINUH works with the United Nations country team, the Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs, UNODC, UNDP and the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights through the United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework for the period 2023–2027. The Office also supports the in-country requirements of the Panel of Experts on Haiti.
With regard to the external factors, the overall plan for 2026 is based on the following planning assumptions:
Political polarization continues to undermine the parties’ ability to achieve the consensus required to advance tangible initiatives to implement political, legal and economic reforms;
The fragile security situation continues to seriously affect both the pace and the sustainability of political, legal and economic reforms;

The Government of Haiti further develops the capacities of the Haitian National Police and its Directorate of Prison Administration, including through the ongoing provision of sufficient budget allocation, complemented by external contributions through a multi-donor basket fund managed by UNDP;
Challenges in the operational capacity of the Multinational Security Support Mission in Haiti curtail political gains significantly;
The impact of hurricanes and earthquakes are not discounted; and
The international donor community and national authorities are unable to agree on stronger coordination arrangements to advance the 2030 Agenda.

The mission integrates a gender perspective into its planning, operations, deliverables and results, as appropriate, and encourages the meaningful participation of women in political processes, dialogues and negotiations, as well as their representation in decision-making positions. Its reporting includes disaggregated data on the impact of human rights violations and abuses on women, and on accountability and justice for crimes of violence against women and girls. In addition, the mission works with civil society actors focusing on gender and human rights in the context of the implementation of recommendations issued by the Committee on the Elimination of Discrimination against Women in 2016 and the second universal periodic review cycle for Haiti, in 2016, on the human rights situation.
Programme performance in 2024
National police authorities improved police performance and enhanced security in Haiti

In 2024, crimes in Haiti, including homicide, kidnapping and rape, rose to unprecedented levels. The number of intentional homicides surged from 4,847 in 2023 to over 7,000 in 2024. BINUH continued to mentor and advise senior national police commanders on effectively addressing criminal networks and gangs, especially on anti-gang operations and intelligence gathering. The mission supported the Haitian National Police in developing a roadmap for the elaboration of a multi-year strategic development plan aimed at strengthening institutional and operational capacities, promoting the rule of law, and enhancing security. The international community has also been actively engaged in efforts to professionalize the Haitian National Police. Advocacy supported by BINUH, for a UNDP-managed multi-donor basket fund has disbursed $14.1 million as of 31 December 2024, including commitments and advances, out of the initial allocated budget of $25.5 million, corresponding to an implementation rate of 54.4 per cent. In addition, a two-year extension (2024-2026) has been granted to the basket fund to allow for the achievement of expected outcomes and the full disbursement of remaining funds. However, the implementation of the planned activities in 2024 has faced delays, primarily due to operational constraints resulting from the worsening security situation and the closure of the international airport.
Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 56).

children.text: Planned results for 2026
Result 1: Increased non-partisans buy-in and constructive engagement towards the implementation of a revised constitution – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

Over the course of 2024, BINUH engaged with key stakeholders, underscoring the importance of holding an inclusive and participative constitutional reform process as a critical step to the holding of general elections. BINUH guided stakeholders through a transition of three successive Prime Ministers within the year accompanying the reshuffling of three ministerial cabinets underscoring the need to maintain focus on the transitional process to complete the constitutional reform process and advance to the holding of general elections. BINUH’s daily advocacy and accompaniment of key players, albeit difficult, has proved an important factor in moving the political process forward.

High Transitional Council was established and launched a national dialogue on electoral and political reforms
Continued divergences among stakeholders and escalating gang violence hamper wider progress in the political process
Advocacy for a sustained and inclusive Haitian-led dialogue on constitutional reforms and elections
Holding a national referendum on constitutional reform and general elections.
Installation of all elected officials at the local, parliamentary and presidential levels.

children.text: Result 2: General elections held, and elected officials installed following a transparent adjudication of electoral contentions – Proposed programme plan for 2026

These will be the first elections since the 2016 electoral process and will re-establish all elected positions in government, allowing a return of functioning, democratic institutions. Key to holding general elections is the restoration of sufficient levels of security and stability, a transparent and efficient Provisional Electoral Council (CEP) and the holding of a constitutional reform referendum. The nine CEP councillors, representing nine sectors of society, have been appointed and in coordination with the Executive Director have initiated a reactivation of the CEP regional and municipal offices.
Lessons learned and planned change

The lesson for the Mission was that the 2015-2017 cycle of elections supported by a peacekeeping operation in the process of withdrawing devolved much of the logistic coordination and transport tasks to the United Nations country team (UNDP and UNOPS). In applying the lesson, BINUH will provide technical advice and guidance and accompany the Haitian leadership and CEP through the electoral process, while coordinating closely with United Nations country team partners to provide the required programmatic support to the government through the joint programme of technical electoral assistance

Resource requirements (regular budget) – Table 59 – Financial resources
(Thousands of United States dollars)
Table 60 – Human resources
a	Other level, unless otherwise stated.

c	Position is funded at 50 per cent and cost-shared with the Development Coordination Office.

The proposed resources for 2026 for BINUH amount to $36,804,900 (net of staff assessment) and would provide for the deployment of 48 United Nations police personnel ($1,139,100), salaries, common staff costs and danger pay ($26,695,900) for 106 international posts and positions (1 Assistant Secretary-General, 1 D-2, 5 D-1, 10 P-5, 27 P-4, 15 P-3, 3 P-2, 44 Field Service) and 73 national posts (24 National Professional Officer, 2 General Service, and 47 Local level, including 2 Local level up to 30 September 2026), 4 international United Nations Volunteers and 3 government-provided personnel, and operational costs ($8,969,900), comprising costs for consultants and consulting services ($94,300), official travel ($336,500), facilities and infrastructure ($4,387,300), ground transportation ($592,700), communications and information technology ($1,738,700), medical ($595,000) and other supplies, services and equipment ($1,204,400).

A vacancy rate of 17.8 per cent has been applied to the estimates for international posts on the basis of the actual vacancy rate in March 2025. A vacancy rate of 33.3 per cent has been applied to the estimates for National Professional Officer posts and a vacancy rate of 12.2 per cent has been applied to the estimates for Local level posts based on the actual vacancy rates in March 2025. A vacancy rate of 50 per cent has been applied to international United Nations Volunteers, and 60.4 per cent to the estimates for United Nations police personnel have been applied based on the actual vacancy rates in March 2025. A vacancy rate of 27.8 per cent has been applied to government-provided personnel on the basis of the average actual vacancy rate during 2024.
The following staffing changes are proposed for 2026:
Police and Corrections Service

Abolishment of one Engineer (P-4) post under the Police and Corrections Service which will no longer be required since UNDP has been employing locally recruited engineers for the Basket Fund’s construction initiatives for the Haitian National Police.
Kuwait Joint Support Office

Transitioning of client missions of Kuwait Joint Support Office (KJSO) to the Regional Service Centre in Entebbe, Uganda: In view of the termination of the mandate of UNAMI on 31 December 2025, it is the intention of the Secretariat to transition the peace operations supported by the KJSO to the RSCE by the end of the UNAMI liquidation process which will end in September 2026. In line with this plan, the current budget contains the proposed abolishment of 2 KJSO posts funded from BINUH, effective 1 October 2026.
The approved 2025 staffing table for BINUH includes five general temporary assistance positions. It is proposed that the positions be continued in 2026, comprising the following:

One Principal Human Rights Officer (D-1) in the Human Rights Service to respond to and address the human rights requirements set by the Security Council as reflected in the BINUH mandate, adopted in resolution 2476 (2019). Such a dedicated position, with specific human rights expertise, is important to facilitate trusted engagement at a high level with senior Haitian authorities, allowing for the provision of technical assistance and advice to the country’s national human rights institutions;
Backstopping support – Department of Political and Peacebuilding Affairs

Three backstopping positions in the Haiti team of the Americas Division of the Department of Political and Peacebuilding Affairs, comprising one Senior Political Affairs Officer (P-5), one Political Affairs Officer (P-4) and one Team Assistant (General Service), who have been providing backstopping support to BINUH since 2019 and will remain critical to ensuring ongoing support and strategic advice and analysis to principals at Headquarters for decision-making with regard to BINUH. The core functions that they undertake are required throughout the lifespan of the mission, including its start-up, the duration of the implementation of its mandate and its closing;
Department of Management Strategy, Policy and Compliance

One Finance and Budget Assistant (General Service) backstopping position in the Field Operations Finance Division, where the need remains high for the continued delivery of high-intensity and high-quality support to legislative bodies in their review of the budgets of special political missions. The continuation of this position will also ensure sufficient capacities for budget preparation, budget administration and performance monitoring of all continuing special political missions.

The increase in requirements for 2026 compared with the appropriation for 2025 is attributable mainly to: (a) increased requirements for international staff due to application of a lower vacancy rate of 17.8 per cent compared to the vacancy rate of 20.7 per cent applied during 2025, revised salary scales for international staff; (b) increased requirements for National Professional Officers and Local level staff due to the revised salary scale, and lower vacancy rate for Local level posts of 12.2 per cent compared to the vacancy rate of 13.7 per cent applied in 2025; (c) increased requirements for facilities and infrastructure due to increased demand for security services; (d) increased requirements for medical services due to increased costs of medical evacuation due to degradation of security environment; (e) increased requirements under other supplies, services and equipment reflecting higher demand for the United Nations Humanitarian Air Services flights due to logistical challenges and cancelation of civil aviation flights, increased freight due to expected receipt of assets from the United Nations reserve. The increased requirements were partially offset by application of a higher vacancy rates for United Nations Police Officers, government-provided personnel and international United Nations Volunteers.
Extrabudgetary resources

In 2025, extrabudgetary resources in the amount of $263,000 are projected to be used to provide resources for two main initiatives: (a) promoting women-led social community dialogues and local conflict prevention initiatives in vulnerable neighbourhoods of Port-au-Prince; (b) enhancing inclusive political participation in Haiti while creating safe and peaceful space for dialogue; and (c) school support to children born as a result of sexual exploitation and abuse by UN personnel in Haiti.
In 2026, extrabudgetary resources in the amount of $238,000 are projected to be used to support the continuation of the above-mentioned projects.
11.	     United Nations Integrated Transition Assistance Mission in Sudan
Liquidation activities

The mandate of the United Nations Integrated Transition Assistance Mission in Sudan (UNITAMS) was outlined in successive Security Council resolutions 2524 (2020), 2579 (2021) and 2636 (2022) and terminated through resolution 2715 (2023). By that resolution, the Council requested the Mission to immediately start on 4 December 2023 the cessation of its operations and the transfer of its tasks, where appropriate and to the extent feasible, to United Nations agencies, funds and programmes, with the objective of completing this by 29 February 2024. The Council decided that the liquidation of UNITAMS should commence on 1 March 2024.
The administrative liquidation of UNITAMS, including the disposal of assets, was carried out from 1 March to 31 December 2024.

The General Assembly, by its resolution 78/274, appropriated the amount of $22.2 million for 2024.  UNITAMS incurred $17.8 million in expenditure for the period, representing a resource utilization rate of 80.5 per cent owing to the pace of liquidation and lower-than-estimated common staff costs for the separation of staff members, including in connection with termination indemnities.
Table 61 – Financial resources
(Thousands of United States dollars)

The process for the drawdown and liquidation of property of UNITAMS was guided by the principles of and policies contained in Financial Rule 105.23. Given the unique circumstances surrounding the closure of UNITAMS, which included the rapidly deteriorating security situation in Sudan and the challenges posed by an active conflict, the process of property disposal within UNITAMS had to be adapted to address the region’s complex operational realities. The mission collaborated extensively with the United Nations Headquarters throughout this period. The mission also engaged with the Government of Sudan on key issues such as adherence to the Status of Mission Agreement, security concerns across various locations across Sudan, and the inability to guarantee environmental cleanup in some operational areas due to the ongoing instability. These challenges significantly influenced the approach adopted for the disposal of property.

Shipping of the United Nations-owned equipment to the United Nations Logistics Base at Brindisi, Italy, or other missions was hindered due to the difficulties in obtaining export clearances, the prohibitive costs associated with shipment for certain items, and the lengthy export procedure, which did not commensurate with the mission’s drawdown timeline. In areas where physical access for verification was blocked due to conflict, or where property had been looted, items were written off as losses due to hostile action.

The assets of UNITAMS, with a total capitalized value/acquisition value of $13,602,100 (corresponding net book value/operational value of $6,634,400), were disposed of as at 31 December 2024, of which 37.4 per cent have been transferred to UN Reserves, with the remaining to recipients including RSCE, UNISFA, UNSOS and others, while 57.7 per cent were written off.
