text: Annex I Summary of follow-up action taken to implement decisions and requests made by the General Assembly, including the requests and recommendations of the Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions endorsed by the Assembly

table_content.text: Action taken to implement the recommendation

Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions
A/79/7/Add.4

Without prejudice, the Committee emphasizes as a matter of general principle that, when a mission is downsizing, it should present a clear exit plan, including with phased abolishments and the reduction of the related non-post resources (para. 18)

UNTMIS is committed to a structured, phased, and transparent transition process. UNTMIS has initiated phase 1 of its two-phased transition process, in line with Security Council resolution 2753 (2024). In January 2025, nine posts were abolished. An additional 15 posts will be abolished by the end of October 2025. The 2026 budget proposal reflects a corresponding reduction in staffing beginning January 2026, aligned with the planned closure of substantive operations in October 2026. A residual presence, covering eight critical functions, will be maintained to support liquidation activities until 31 December 2026.
Following the issuance of the Secretary-General’s Planning Directive on Somalia on 12 March 2025, which provides strategic guidance for the planning, preparation and implementation of the UN transition in Somalia, UNTMIS is taking all necessary steps and actions regarding its implementation. 
The Secretary-General shared a transition roadmap for phase 1 of the transition with the Security Council by the end of March 2025.
Accordingly, all cost-shared services with UNSOS for the provision of logistical services have been budgeted to cover the budget period until 31 October 2026, the end of phase 2 of the Mission’s transition and the anticipated termination of its mandate.

The Advisory Committee trusts that an update on the UNSMIL staffing review will be provided to the General Assembly at the time of its consideration of the present report, as well as in the next budget submission (para. 20)

The Mission conducted a comprehensive staffing review from September 2024 to March 2025. The review aimed to align staffing resources with mandate priorities and operational needs, and to assess the Mission support structure in line with the Department for Operational Support guidelines. 
By its resolution 2755 (2024), the Security Council requested the Secretary-General to submit a strategic review of UNSMIL to the Council no later than 30 September 2025, including recommendations for increasing the efficiency and effectiveness of UNSMIL’s overall structure, including the objectives of UNSMIL.  
As the strategic review will be finalized after the 2026 proposed programme budget, the outcome of the staffing review is not reflected in the current budget for 2026, as the Mission awaits the outcome of strategic review to ensure alignment with the Mission’s long-term strategic direction, and future Security Council decisions.

The Committee, however, recognizes the importance of information and data technology expertise and considers that a vacant professional-level post at UNMHA might be repurposed to fulfil that function, as appropriate (see also A/78/7, para. 42) (para. 29)

In preparation for the 2026 budget submission, UNMHA has thoroughly reviewed its staffing complement and identified a vacant post of Coordination Officer (P-3) in Djibouti previously supporting the air medical evacuation services, which is no longer required due to the change in operational arrangements. As a result, this post is proposed for abolishment and a new post of Data Specialist
(P-3) is proposed for establishment, while the overall staffing level remained unchanged. This is fully in line with the recommendation of the Committee to repurpose vacant professional-level post.

The Advisory Committee trusts that UNOWAS will continue to make its aircraft available, on a cost-reimbursable basis, to other United Nations system entities in the region, when possible, and looks forward to an update thereon in the next budget submission (para. 52)
UNOWAS will continue to make its aircraft available, on a cost-recovery basis to other United Nations system entities in the region, when possible.

The Advisory Committee trusts that UNMHA will ensure that quick-impact projects result in tangible benefits for the local communities, with a view to a positive long-term legacy, and trusts that an update will be included in the next budget submission (para. 53)

Quick-impact projects have been integral to the UNMHA efforts to build confidence towards the Hudaydah Agreement and foster trust among stakeholders. UNMHA has leveraged quick-impact projects in enhancing its engagement with the parties to the Hudaydah Agreement and focused on thematic areas on women, income generation, education and the health sector in designing its quick-impact projects to have the intended impact of confidence and trust building. An impact assessment will be conducted in 2025 that will review the contributions quick-impact projects have made to progressing the mandate and the tangible benefits they have brought to beneficiaries. The findings and lessons learned from the impact assessment will be used to inform future design and implementation of its quick-impact projects, as well as be shared with other special political missions

The Advisory Committee trusts that the special political missions under cluster III will continue their efforts to achieve a more equitable geographical representation of Member States among their staff in all categories and will provide related updates in future budget submissions. (para. 55)

Mission under this thematic cluster remain committed to equitable geographical representation and diversity in line with the United Nations objectives. Efforts have been made to ensure an inclusive recruitment process that reflects Member States’ representation while upholding competence, efficiency, and integrity.
Proactive measures, including outreach and targeted vacancy dissemination, have encouraged applications from underrepresented Member States within operational constraints. 
Some missions (such as UNSCOL, UNSMIL, BINUH) use the monthly updates on equitable geographical distribution status is being shared with leadership and hiring managers are regularly briefed on their responsibilities to give priority to candidates from non-represented and underrepresented Member States.
UNSMIL Human Resources Unit regularly analyses the composition of its staff using various data sets, including fresh data from the management dashboard, to identify gaps in geographical representation. 
BINUH reaches out to rostered candidates from unrepresented and underrepresented countries and encourages them to apply, especially female candidates.
The Advisory Committee trusts that the special political missions under cluster III will make efforts to achieve gender balance among their staff. (para. 56)

Mission under this thematic cluster remain committed to achieve gender balance among their staff in line with the United Nations principles. Efforts have been made to ensure an inclusive recruitment process that considers gender balance. while upholding competence, efficiency, and integrity.
UNSCOL reached a balance of 56 per cent women and 44 per cent men. Other missions, including UNOCA, UNSMIL, UNVMC, UNMHA, and BINUH, are making further efforts to achieve full gender balance, including through outreach activities and training of hiring managers. UNTMIS, as an entity in liquidation, is focused on maintaining operational continuity and a responsible drawdown, limiting major shifts in workforce composition. 
BINUH is experiencing additional challenges in attracting female national candidates due to the operational environment.

Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions
A/79/7/Add.26

The Advisory Committee notes that Security Council resolution 2753 (2024) was adopted on 30 October 2024 and trusts that the detailed transition, asset disposal, including fixed assets, and liquidation plans of UNTMIS, as well as the related post and non-post requirements, taking into consideration lessons learned from previous mission closures, will be included in the next budget submission (para. 6)

Detailed transition, asset disposal and liquidation plans for UNTMIS are integrated into its transition and liquidation plan, activities and budget proposals. 
The preliminary asset disposal plan for UNTMIS provides a structured framework for asset disposal by coordinating with relevant stakeholders to determine ownership and the most appropriate methods for disposition.
Current analysis indicates the following data: 
•37.54 % assets and equipment will be shipped or redeployed to other peacekeeping missions.
•55.49 % assets and equipment will be disposed of locally through commercial sale, scrapping, or destruction.
• 6.2 % assets and equipment will be donated to the Federal Government of Somalia (FGS) upon request.
To expedite the process, UNTMIS established an Asset Disposal Task Force, which oversees and facilitates disposal of UNOE for UNTMIS entity. 
Moreover, drawing on lessons learned from previous mission closures, the preliminary asset disposal plan criteria have been refined to focus on ensuring efficient disposal based on asset condition, life expectancy, and cost-effectiveness. UNTMIS is confident that these comprehensive measures will address all aspects of the transition and disposal process as required.

The Committee trusts that the available allotment will be managed efficiently during the final two months of the 2024 budget period and that the future requirements for UNTMIS will be based on realistic budget assumptions (para. 8)

During the budget period, UNTMIS put in place austerity measures such as a freeze on non-critical acquisitions, non-essential travel and training and a review of its scope of logistical support services in order to manage the available allotment for 2024. The 2025 and 2026 budget proposals were based on realistic budget assumptions and cost drivers for implementing the two transition phases of UNTMIS.
The Advisory Committee trusts that detailed information and a breakdown of the separation costs for all the personnel will be provided in the next budget submission (para. 11)

The proposed resources under salaries and other costs also include a provision of $17,464,300 for payments due to staff members at the time of separation from service. 61. The provision comprises estimated termination indemnity ($6,586,300), repatriation grants ($5,042,000), relocation grants ($1,778,000), accrued annual leave for international and national staff ($3,692,600), travel expenses to cover repatriation of international staff ($365,400).

The Advisory Committee notes that, during the first and second phases of the transition, some encumbered and vacant posts could be repurposed for other operationally required tasks, as appropriate, and trusts that UNTMIS will review its staffing requirements on a continuous basis, with a view to abolishing, in particular, the vacant posts that are not under recruitment, and submit them for the consideration of the General Assembly in the next UNTMIS budget proposal (para. 21)

The drawdown of UNTMIS staffing is currently already underway. The approved 2025 budget reflects a net reduction of 24 civilian posts and five military/police positions, in accordance with phase 1 of the transition agreed with the Federal Government of Somalia. Effective 1 January 2025, eight international posts and five military/police positions were abolished. One international D-1 position has been reassigned within the Mission, and three international staff posts, along with three UNV posts, were nationalised. Effective 1 July 2025, one general temporary assistance D-1 position will be abolished. Finally, to conclude phase 1 of the transition on 1 November 2025, eight international staff positions, six national staff positions, and one international general temporary assistance position will be abolished. This phased approach ensures that UNTMIS staffing adjustments align with the agreed modalities while maintaining operational continuity. Transition planning for phase 2 of the transition is progressing in consultation with the Federal Government of Somalia through the established Joint Technical Committee. The Mission’s budget proposal for 2026 includes the abolishment of eleven posts and positions effective 1 January 2026. Furthermore, all remaining UNTMIS posts and positions will be abolished by 31 October 2026, except for a small team of 8 posts to carry out residual activities. This timeline is subject to the Security Council's decisions and the modalities it may establish for the second and final phase of the UNTMIS transition.

Notwithstanding the ongoing transition of UNTMIS, the Advisory Committee reiterates the importance of nationalising posts and positions, which will offer new work experiences to staff and build national capacity. The Committee trusts that efforts will be made by UNTMIS to assist national staff at all levels in finding employment opportunities, including by collaborating with the United Nations country team, as well as other international and national agencies present in the country. The Committee looks forward to an update thereon in the next budget submission (para. 22)

UNTMIS, during its closure, will pursue, within available resources, other means of career transition support for national staff, such as enhanced focus on training and certifications and career fairs with other United Nations entities and similar potential employers.
UNTMIS will pursue within available resources, other means of career transition support for national staff, such as enhanced focus on training and certifications, career fairs with other UN entities and similar potential employers.
All necessary support as applicable for UNTMIS national staff in accordance with the downsizing policy (ST/AI/2023/1) and resources and liquidity permitting will be provided.
The Advisory Committee encourages continuous efforts to build national staff capacity through repurposing of the existing resource requirements (para 25).

UNTMIS, through the UNSOS Integrated Mission Training Centre, is finalizing its 2025 training and capacity-building plan for national staff, drawing on a training needs assessment, the results of a Mach 2025 survey targeting UNTMIS national staff, and feedback on national staff training needs received from substantive components.
Capacity-building initiatives planned for phase 1 of the UNTMIS transition focus on enhancing essential skills, capacities, and capabilities required for the continued delivery of the Mission mandate and on career development opportunities beyond the lifecycle of UNTMIS. 
Given the liquidity constraints and continued austerity measures, all training initiatives will either be offered in-mission or online, thereby maximizing the number of national staff benefitting from them. A particular emphasis is placed on certification training.
In addition, the Mission will support the cross-training of interested national staff in other UNTMIS substantive sections, in agreement with respective supervisors, to broaden the professional experience of existing staff and facilitate synergies.

The Advisory Committee considers that, at this stage in the life cycle of UNTMIS, the capitalisation of all existing, ongoing and planned investments, including construction, maintenance and rehabilitation, should be carefully considered in view of the forthcoming disposal of assets and the future use of the compound (para. 27)

The Advisory Committee's recommendation has been fully taken into account. Accordingly, no new major construction projects are planned or proposed in the UNTMIS budget. Ongoing construction activities are limited to regular maintenance and minor construction activities to ensure the sustainability of critical infrastructure, including offices, accommodations, bunkers, and perimeter fortifications, in order to mitigate the threat of rocket attacks. In addition, only minor repairs and facility upgrades are being undertaken across Mogadishu and other sectors. The Mission remains committed to ensuring that the disposal of assets and decisions regarding the future use of the compound will be conducted in accordance with the established guidelines.

The Advisory Committee trusts that more detailed information, including the related resources for the logistical support package provided by UNSOS on a cost-recovery basis, will be included in the next budget submissions of both UNTMIS and UNSOS (para. 29)

UNTMIS confirms that as required by UN Security Council resolution 2741 (2024), UNTMIS has included provision for resources reimbursement on cost recovery basis for administrative and logistical support package provided by UNSOS for 2026. The reimbursement includes costs for the provision of human resource, finance, logistics, technical services and procurement services. The costs have been determined based on workload statistics specific to different functions.
